title: DC COVID-19 Outbreaks
description: The data describes COVID-19 outbreaks that occur at various setting types. Data are presented by setting type (school building, university, office building, etc.) by week.Data is updated on a weekly basis.

title: Enterprise Dataset Inventory as of March 2020
description: Mayor's Order 2017-115 establishes a comprehensive data policy for the District government. The data created and managed by the District government are valuable assets and are independent of the information systems in which the data reside. As such, the District government shall:Maintain an inventory of its enterprise datasets;Classify enterprise datasets by level of sensitivity;Regularly publish the inventory, including the classifications, as an open dataset; andStrategically plan and manage its investment in data.The greatest value from the District’s investment in data can only be realized when enterprise datasets are freely shared among District agencies, with federal and regional governments, and with the public to the fullest extent consistent with safety, privacy, and security. For more information, please visit https://opendata.dc.gov/pages/edi-overview. Previous years of EDI can be found on Open Data DC.

title: Cumulative FOIA Report FY 2020
description: In accordance with the District of Columbia Freedom of Information Act, attached please find the annual report of the public-record-disclosure activities of each public body of the District government between October 1, 2019, and September 30, 2020 ("FY 2020"). The report contains available data responsive to the annual report required under D.C. Official Code § 2538(a) and consists of the following documents: 1. District Government-Wide Cumulative FOIA Report;2. Spreadsheet Breakdown of FOIA Data by Agency;

title: DC Cherry Trees Near Me
description: Find out which beautiful cherry trees are near you this spring season. Data from DDOT Urban Forestry Division's street trees dataset.

title: Liquor License Cancellations
description: This dataset represents ABCA liquor license cancellations. Cancellations are processed at the request of the licensee or administratively when a licensee fails to pay annual and renewal fees. Data is updated as ABCA completes renewal and annual payment cycles.

title: Addressing in DC
description:
Addressing in DC Address Points Address Points Address Points Address Residential Units RESIDENTIAL UNITS Addresses Residential Units Points of Interest Points of Interest - MAR Aliases Points of Interest The District of Columbia government uses the Master Address Repository (MAR) to implement intelligent search functionality for finding and verifying addresses, place names, blocks and intersections. It provides complete standardization of addressing components so that agency applications and systems maintain clean integration. Most often the MAR is solely known for its address points. Did you know uses of the MAR go beyond DC government and are available for public use in your applications with web services and geocoding tools? Take a look at what we've done with it and then make it your own. Foundational Data Address Locations | 
		Documentation | 
		Tools and Development | 
		Related Data | 
		Common Questions Find More MAR Data Documentation Before the MAR The format and quality of address information varied considerably across government enterprise systems, making it nearly impossible to identify all of the activity associated with a given address. Police reports recorded by MPD likely contained different addressing formats than drivers licenses at the DMV. Address anomalies, which do not fit logically into the DC address grid, were never tracked or accounted for. We have all seen these types of locations such as even numbered addresses incorrectly found on odd side of streets. Benefits of MAR Now, addressing standards are built in. They define the valid components of DC addresses (Address Number, Street Name, Street Type, Quadrant), including their correct formatting and spelling. It also includes related datasets for intersections, blocks and points of interest for prominent locations. The data was assembled from years of research of more than 20 address databases, like the US Postal Service, and it continues to be updated daily. This allows District agencies to more easily compare address information across all databases. For example, the 911 call center uses the exact same addressing system as the Department of Energy & Environment's storm water management teams. Tools and Development Quick Lookup The District created a nice, easy to use, website where anyone can search for a single address or square suffix lot. Just use one of our standard methods to get quick information. What Ward are you located in? What is your police district? What else? MAR Web Geocoder The MAR Web Geocoder is a web browser-based tool for geocoding locations, typically addresses, in Washington, DC. It is developed by the Office of Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) and can input Excel or CSV files to output an Excel file. Data will be appended with geographic attributes from the District's Master Address Repository. Get started with the user guide. MAR Web Services The MAR 2 API and web services provide a variety of methods to perform geocoding and address verification. Developers can create single address lookup or batch processing through the MAR. The MAR 2 API provides RESTful services with json outputs while the Legacy MAR web services use SOAP services with xml and json outputs. Search Addresses Batch Geocoding Reverse Geocoding Find Zones MAR 2 APIAllows users to search for addresses, place names, blocks and intersections within the DC boundary. MAR 2 APIThe preferred method for the bulk geocoding of addresses over cycling through and locating each address in a list. MAR 2 APIUse latitude and longitude coordinates to reverse lookup nearby addresses and the zones they are contained by. MAR 2 APIGet information regarding associated boundaries like ANC, police district, census tract, and Ward. Legacy MAR Relate with Other Datasets It's easy to relate the MAR with datasets across DC government. The MAR is stored in an Oracle enterprise relational database with over 20 unique tables and linked to the Department of Transportation's street spatial database. Look for these common unique identifiers to relate with many of the datasets offered in Open Data DC. Use the desktop geocoder to assign ADDRESS_ID to your data and link up to the property layers below. Address & SSLCross Reference Common Ownership Lots Computer AidedMass Appraisal Integrated TaxSystem Extract A table to cross reference the District's address points with the square suffix and lot boundaries. A conflated layer by Square, Suffix and Lot to include: Air Rights, Record, Parcel, Tax and Reservation lots. Contains attribution on housing characteristics for residential, commercial and condominiums. Chief Financial Officer’s property tax data for assessments, rates, sales, use type and more. Property Lots in DC Common Questions Who is responsible for the MAR? The OCTO Data team which is part of the Office of the Chief Technology Officer is responsible for maintaining the MAR. The Department of Buildings (DOB) is responsible for approving new addresses. The DC Department of Transportation (DDOT) is responsible for maintaining certain information regarding streets. How are individual addresses verified? Many sources are checked during the address verification process. The more sources that recognize the candidate address, the more likely it will be added to the MAR. Below are some sources that are being used for address verification: Are there many cases of illogical addresses? Yes. There are dozens of addresses that are illogical. These are illogical because they do not follow the normal rules of Washington, DC's addressing grid system. These illogical addresses are also referred to as address anomalies. Learn more in the Address Anomalies report. The District continuously works to track down these cases and ensuring that the address database matches the reality on the street. How accurately mapped are the Address Records? The address records have a very high level of spatial accuracy. Address records should be located either at or near the center of the building or near the main entrance of the address. It is estimated that there are less than 70 addresses (~ .05%) that are not located within the correct building footprint. There has been a tremendous effort invested in ensuring a very high level of spatial accuracy. This allows for excellent point in polygon analysis. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Property Lots in DC
description:
Property Lots in DC Condo Relate Table CONDORELATE Active Condomium Lots Computer Assisted Mass Appraisal - Commercial COMMERCIAL (CAMA) Commercial Properties Tax Exempt Properties TAX EXEMPT PROPERTY (RPTA) Tax Exempt Properties Property or parcel data is a critical layer to any city or statewide data holdings. In our city's complex urban environment, this includes numerous geographies that identify federal government lands, reservations, District lands, personal property and so much more. The District's Vector Property Mapping (VPM) project works daily to capture property lot transactions so that city planners, business development leaders and residents stay current. Read below to help you identify how DC lot data is organized and key points on their relationships. Foundational Data Recorded Lands | 
		Documentation | 
		Condominium | 
		Tools and Development | 
		Tax Assessment | 
		Related Data | 
		Changes in Lots | 
		Common Questions DC Real Property Finder Recorded Lands and Taxation The Office of Tax and Revenue (OTR) maintains a database known as the Integrated Tax System (ITS) containing the accounts for real estate property. ITS records property transactions, such as reconfigured lots & ownership change, as they occur during a given fiscal year. DC government's fiscal year begin October 1st and ends September 30th. Below are the six different lot types in the District. Individually, these key layers make up most of the District's property boundaries. Together, they make up a single layer known as the common ownership lots and dimensions. Find More VPM Data Common Ownership Lots Considered a primary data set to begin working with. This polygon layer is built from the various lot types in the District. The common ownership dataset is conflated by Square, Suffix and Lot to include: Air Rights, Record, Parcel, Tax and Reservation lots. Some Parcels and Reservations fall outside of a Square’s boundary.  It does NOT include condominiums. Refer to the Condo Relate Table and Condo Approval Lot data. Documentation Vector Property Mapping (VPM) Vector property mapping data is recorded and maintained with the oversight of the Office of Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), Office of the Surveyor, and the Real Property Tax Administration (RPTA). The data you see here represents active lots as of September 1, 2006. Prior to this date, lot history was not created or property transactions have since been applied to keep the data current. If you're interested in lot history, these can still be found utilizing other publicly available resources such as the Office of the Surveyor’s SurDocs management system (Square cards, Plats, and miscellaneous documents), baist books, and property scans. Benefits of VPM Benefits of the VPM project extend from within District government to the public and private users of the data. Innovative use of geospatial technology continues to improve business processes of the three agencies that manage land records. The semi-automated subdivision and building plat production process creates a faster turnaround time for plats and constituent access. The extensive data depicts active citywide lots with the ability to display history and change of property over time. Condominium Approved Lots The Condo Approval Lots layer was created to assist you in identifying the relationship between ground surface lots, overlay lots and their associated condominiums. It helps users research the original source material recorded in the Office of the Surveyor and view their boundaries. Condo dwellings can also be found using the individual active record lots, dead air rights and tax lots where the value in the UNDERLIES_CONDO field is equal to 1. Approved for Ground When condos are approved for ground lots (aka, record lots), those remain in the condo approval layer. Its attributions are also updated to reflect them. The following fields are populated once condo lots have been approved: Approved for Overlay When condos are approved for overlay lots (aka, air rights and tax lots), those now become dead lots and archived to their respective history layer. Search for these by performing a query where the value in the UNDERLIES_CONDO field is equal to 1. Condo Relationships These tables are related based on the REGIME value and will help to quantify the number of condos residing on a lot - grouping of condos. The regime number starts with a 1, 2, or 3 depending upon where the condo is located and where they fall in the tax assessment process. All numbers after the first are consecutive. Use REGIME as a primary key between these tables. Tools and Development Property Web Services Web services are a series of APIs which primarily call DC Government’s MAR. These operations return a wealth of information about locations in Washington, DC offered as XML based returns (.NET and SOAP) and JSON. Great news! These APIs are freely available to all users, not just DC gov. By using the MAR web services, users can take advantage of DC's authoritative data sources including the best available source of addressing and street network. By SSL By Address By X,Y Coordinates By Parcel Lot findBySquareSuffixLotAccepts three input parameters: square (required), suffix, and lot. Returns associated Condos, Addresses, Air Rights, Tax, Parcel, Record and Reservation lots. findByAddressOne input parameter: address or intersection. Returns Air Rights, Tax, Parcel, Record, Reservation lots and Condos associated with the input address or intersection. findByXYTwo required input parameters: x & y coordinates in meters. Returns Address, Air Rights, Tax, Parcel, Record and Reservation lots for which the x,y is located inside. findByParcelLotTwo required input parameters: parcel and lot. Returns Addresses of Air Rights, Tax, Parcel, Record and Reservation lots associated with the input parcel and lot. Find More Web Services Integrated Tax Assessment Public Extract The tax assessment roll public extract (ITSPE) is used for assessment and property analysis, to send property tax bills and notices, and stores comprehensive tax information such as ownership, mailing addresses, non-contiguous Air Rights lots (Multifamily or Development), Air Rights lots, possessory interest lots, record lots, tax lots, parcels, condominiums, and federally owned lands such as reservations and appropriations. The linkage from the Vector Property layers to this database is SSL (Square, Suffix, and Lot). Considerations It should be noted that not all record lots have a direct 1:1 relationship to information in this database. The most obvious examples would be when a tax lot was created from existing record lots. In this case, only the tax lot would have linkage to the ITSPE, not the underlying record lots (though they still exist). Reservations that have been converted into tax lots are an additional example where the reservation still exists, however for taxation purposes the tax lot (overlay) supersedes and has corresponding linkage to ITS. The same is true for most Condominiums and the ground surface lot (Record) which still exist (common space) or the previous overlay (Air Right or Tax lot), only the Condo lot would have linkage to (ITSPE). Relate with Other Datasets Property data is stored in an Oracle enterprise database with several inter-related datasets and maintenance activities. Some of these occur automatically while others are manually generated. Use the key identifiers below to relate across other layers in Open Data DC. View the timestamps for transactions as they are recorded. Find More VPM Data Maintenance Chief Technology Office Office of the Surveyor Real Property Tax Administration *Some activities that are truly shared across multiple agencies. Complete functional roles for each are found VPM Maintenance Requirements. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: MAR Overview Presentation
description: The District of Columbia government uses the Master Address Repository (MAR) to implement intelligent search functionality for finding and verifying addresses, place names, blocks and intersections. It provides complete standardization of addressing components so that agency applications and systems maintain clean integration. Most often the MAR is solely known for its address points. But did you know it is also a web data service, a standalone app, a toolbar and website? Did you know uses of the MAR go beyond DC government and are available for public use in your applications? Take a look at what we've done with it and then make it your own.

title: MAR Address Standards
description:
This Address Standards document has been developed to describe the addressing standards used for the Master Address
		Repository (MAR). The MAR is DC Government’s official address database and is widely used across the City of
		Washington, DC. The OCTO Data Team which is part of the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), is
		responsible for maintaining the MAR.

title: MAR Frequently Asked Questions
description:
The MAR allows the District Government to more easily compare information across databases and
		agencies. Learn more about the MAR with these frequently asked questions.

title: Legacy MAR Data Dictionary
description:
The Master Address Repository (MAR) is a complex and widely accessed database that is increasingly
		being accessed by many DC Government applications. For such a widely used databases, it is important
		to have high quality documentation readily accessible. As a result, this document contains the table
		definitions for the most important views, tables and feature classes within the MAR.

title: MAR Address Anomalies
description:
An address anomaly is an address whose
		location is illogical. In other words, the address
		does not follow the normal rules of the District
		of Columbia’s (DC) addressing grid system.
		There are different types of anomalies.

title: Changes in Lots
description:
How Property Lots Change The District's Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), Office of Tax and Revenue (OTR)Real Property Tax Administration (RPTA), and Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affair's (DCRA) Surveyor's Office (OS) manage the vector property map data. OCTO's primary responsibility is data distribution, project support and mapping of Federal lands, while RPTA & OS are responsible for data maintenance and property transactions. Foundational Data Recorded Lands | 
		Documentation | 
		Condominium | 
		Tools and Development | 
		Related Data | 
		Changes in Lots | 
		Common Questions Methods There are two methods for creating new property boundaries. First, via the Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affair's (DCRA) Surveyor's Office where they will generate a Subdivision upon request. Second, from OTR's Real Property Mapping and Assessment Division where they will generate Assessment & Taxation Plats. The District maintains a history of lots as real estate transactions occur, such as sales or development. Ground Surface Lots These records and reservations are considered ground lots and can only be combined, subdivided, or killed by itself. It is why in most scenarios you can only obtain a building permit for record lots. Reservations were acquired by the Federal government by purchase, condemnation, dedication or as a gift. Almost all U.S. reservations are under the Jurisdiction of the National Park Service. Note that both may have superseding tax lots for land tracking purposes. The "of-lot" Process: A ground lot can also become an of-lot if and when there is an overlay that is being subdivided for development or sale. An of-lot is the D.C. Surveyor’s Office term for describing Remaining Part of Original Lot. Sometimes this is done to obtain permitting. If a value of 1 is in the OF_LOT_SEQ field, you can assume that at one time the original lot was modified. Typically, any of these of-lots will also have a tax lot overlapping them since it is a piece or remainder of a record lot. There are approximately 11,500 of-lots. History of Recorded Lands and Taxation A history of lot changes dating back to 2006. If you're interested in additional lot history, view other publicly available resources such as the Office of the Surveyor’s SurDocs management system (Square cards, Plats, and miscellaneous documents), Baist books, and property scan images. Zoning and Development The Zoning Commission is authorized to approve Planned Unit developments (PUD). The PUD process provides for higher quality development through flexibility in building controls, including height and density. Although assumes the result is superior to what would result from a matter-of-right development and offer a commendable number or quality of meaningful public benefits including – including protect and advance public health, safety, welfare, and convenience, and is not inconsistent with the Comprehensive Plan. The Development Report is a summary of major development and construction projects. The Washington DC Economic Partnership (WDCEP) tracks these throughout the year and performs an annual “census” in the month of August. This research and outreach receives contribution from more than 100 developers, architects, contractors, and economic development organizations. This results in updates to 400 plus projects. Although every attempt is made to ensure the quality of the information contained in the report, WDCEP makes no warranty or guarantee as to its accuracy, completeness, or usefulness for any given purpose. Land Boundary Changes View land boundary changes and keep track of yearly change with the recorded date, RECORDATION_DT. This layer is derived from the Common Ownership Lots and represents property transactions as they’ve occurred since the implementation of the Vector Property Mapping program in September 2006. A property transaction entails new geometry (split/combination of Lot(s) or property type conversion (from Air Rights, Record, or Tax Lots to Condo lots). The layer contains locations and attributes of archived features (inactive lots – dead lots) and corresponds with OTR's Public Extract files (ITSPE). The data was created as part of the DC Geographic Information System (DC GIS) for the DC Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) and participating DC government agencies (Office of the Surveyor (OS) & Real Property Tax Administration (RPTA). The creation of this layer is automated. It occurs weekly for the current calendar year and geometry updated when a transaction occurs. Common Questions How can I access and view VPM data? These property data, along with hundreds of others, are all available for download here. When viewing the results for each page users are offered the option to open a preview in ArcGIS Online - a free map viewer. Just click Create Webmap from the About section. Other popular DC government apps for viewing are, What does cadastral mean and how is it related to VPM? DC's VPM data are referred to as a group of cadastral GIS layers. A cadstral map shows political and property boundaries as well as ownerhip of lands. How are addresses and a piece of property related? It is a many-to-many relationship where one lot can have multiple addresses on it. Think of downtown buildings with corner stores. Likewise, one structure with a single address could potentially cross two lots. Where can I find the property use type? The Property Use Code List Lookup domain table will identify the various use types. These codes appear as the USECODE field in many of DC's property layers. Is VPM data considered a legal field survey? Short answer, NO. This is very important. These are representations of property boundaries but should not be used for property line disputes. A licensed land surveyor is the only legal means of determining property boundaries. The VPM data in most cases will never be as accurate as a legal survey; it is difficult to maintain a dataset at that accuracy when you have over 180,000 properties city-wide and only about 7% have been field surveyed. Furthermore, cadastral maps provide an approximation of property location for taxing purposes. A land survey provides a legal document that is admissible in court. For boundary disputes questions/issues, individuals should contact DCRA's Office of Surveyor Services. If VPM is not legal, then how do I obtain a legal plat of my land? Depending on your needs you could obtain a deed through the Recorder of Deeds or a plat from Surveyor Services. Is VPM data perfect? Dare to dream. We think we do a pretty good job of capturing cadastral data in DC and we acknowledge that there are weaknesses. The data is not 100% real-time. There is a lag between the time it takes for a boundary change to be approved by DCRA or OTR, and how it makes its way into VPM. Also, square data is not tied to survey points.  Each square is a free floating entity and thus is a "best-fit" to ground level. There are no control points (x,y) for squares to tie them to real world coordinates. If you think your square and/or lot's placement can be "better fit" to its surrounding physical features such as buildings, please send and email to open.data@dc.gov. how can I identify what lot type each of the polygons are? In the Common Ownership Lots dataset, take a look at the LOT_TYPE attribute column of the data. This column contains a series of coded values identified below. For example, records lots are equal to 1. If you performed a filter such as LOT_TYPE=1 you'll find all the District's record lots. In the SSL identifier, how do I interpret the Lot numbers? SSL are 12 characters in length. The first 4 characters are your Square. The middle 4 characters, if present, are your Suffix and last 4 characters are your lot. Therefore, How are Suffix values formatted within a SSL identifier? Let's answer this using a series of "if, then" statements. SSL are 12 characters in length. The first 4 characters are your Square. The middle 4 characters, if present, are your Suffix and last 4 characters are your lot. Therefore, Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: DC from Above
description:
DC from Above Sidewalks Sidewalks Sidewalks & Stairs Roadway Block Roadway Block Roadway Blocks Building Footprints Building Footprints Building Footprints Since its inception in 2000, the District has collected Orthophotography and now LiDAR. These aerial images have a variety of uses including web based visualizations and to create derivative data such as buildings, roads and elevation models. They are viewed in many District web applications and made available as downloadable files. They can also be accessed as web services to integrate into your web apps. Foundational Data Aerial Imagery | 
		Planimetric Data | 
		LiDAR | 
		Oblique Imagery | 
		Tools and Development | 
		Common Questions Pan and zoom with the 2008 image so that other years will sync or switch by clicking the circular arrows. Aerial Imagery & Orthophotography Preview and Compare Imagery The planning, detail and coordination between us, the United States government and other key partners are a great deal. Timing is everything in these projects. We always plan to fly in late winter when leaves haven't sprung yet and shadowing is minimal during the best time of day. However sometimes it just doesn't work out. This is why perhaps you'll see more obscure areas as shadows in some imagery, or too much leaf coverage. Nonetheless, the data we derive from these images are valuable to us and you! An Aerial History In the mid-1990's, before DC GIS, the National Capital Planning Commission (NCPC) and DC government departments teamed up to obtain aerial imagery for survey work. The resulting 1995 and 1999 images were used to support government operations in planning, property assessment and public works. The 1995 and 1999 aerial projects compiled the imagery at 1 foot resolution. For its time this was considered great detail. However in comparison, the city's two most recent flights captured images at 3 inch resolution. This means that for every pixel, we are providing you 3 inches of ground cover. Latest High Resolution Imagery The project was flown on March 11, 2021 at an average altitude of 3,000 feet. The aerial imagery acquisition was flown to support the creation of 4-band digital orthophotography with a 3 inch/0.08 meter pixel resolution over the full project area covering the District of Columbia which is approximately 69 square miles. The data are available as both JPEG2000 and a compressed geospatial SID file. Customers who would like the full 328 GeoTIFF files will need to make special arrangements with the Open Data team; the complete catalog is approximately 124GB. Below are aerial images for you to preview and download. This dataset provided as an ArcGIS Image service. Please note, the download feature for this image service provides a compressed PNG, JPEG or TIFF. The compressed  multiresolution seamless images (MrSID) or JPEG2000 files are found under additional options when viewing download options. 2008 Aerial Image 2010 Aerial Image 2012 Aerial Image Historic Map Plans Captured with 16 cm resolution. Captured with 6 inch resolution. Captured with 6 inch resolution. Scanned for historic preservation. 1995 Aerial Image 1999 Aerial Image 2002 Aerial Image 2005 Aerial Image The following years are only available as download in MrSID format. Captured with 1 foot resolution. Captured with 1 foot resolution. Captured with 1 foot resolution. Captured with 6 inch resolution. Planimetric Data The District creates several foundational datasets referred to as Planimetric data with each aerial flight project. These are things like building footprints, streets, sidewalks, recreation areas, bridges, curbs, hydrography and on and on and on. We make it all freely accessible on Open Data DC as owners of this data and imagery. It is one of the DC Office of the Chief Technology Officer's Data division's largest bi-annual projects and certainly seems like the center of attention. This operational data is used across government agencies to extend and further improve upon their work. These support projects like, Our city's infrastructure continues to expand or be redesigned as we welcome new residents, business and services. These foundational datasets are available from every year we completed an aerial flight project. Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) Captured in Winter, 2022 Browse all DC LiDAR LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging), is a remote sensing method that uses light in the form of a pulsed laser to measure variable distances to the District's surface. The data collected is known as point cloud dataset which includes x, y, and z coordinates with additional details that can help classify landscape features. The z coordinates are what give us the three-dimensional space. The District of Columbia has published new LiDAR captured on January 24, 2022 with a short re-flight on January 26, 2022. The previous LiDAR effort was done in 2018, 2015 and 2020. The 2022 data includes vegetation classifications and building classifications. The DSM, DTM and nDSM are provided at 1 meter resolution. You will notice that voids exist due to data redaction conducted under the guidance of the United States Secret Service, and based on the redaction areas generated in 2017. Neighborhood Snapshots at 45° The DC Oblique Analyst web app displays 45 degree images for any location. There are two catalogs available for you - Fall of 2014 and Spring of 2015. An array of five digital cameras capture beautiful DC oblique (angled) and nadir (straight-down) views. This enables users to visualize, measure and analyze all sides of a structure or ground feature. Lean how to use. Cardozo Education Campus Captured on April 5, 2015 Go Directly to Cardozo The historic "Castle on the Hill," Francis L. Cardozo Education Campus pictured here is one of hundreds of neighborhood level images. This 300 foot recreation field is an example of how you can use DC Oblique Analyst  to measure structures and lands. DC government is most heavily using these images in areas of first responses/emergency management, urban planning, and property assessment. How will you use this catalog? Tools and Development Web Map Services DC makes all its orthophotography available as map services via ArcGIS Server REST Endpoints. Use these in your web applications and desktop tools. Esri Image Services Provides quick access to hosted imagery and raster data in ArcGIS Pro, web map clients, and other desktop, mobile apps and OGC Web Map Service (WMS), Web Coverage Service (WCS), Web Map Tile Service (WMTS), and Keyhole Markup Language (KML) services. Common Questions How often does DC government capture Orthophotography and LiDAR? We try to collect Orthophotography and update planimetric data every other year. As events in government progress we will do our best to keep our users informed. Follow us  @OpenDataDC on Twitter. What geographic projection are DC's aerial photos in? Most aerial photos are projected in Web Mercator, such as those highlighted on this page. However, the same images are also projected in Maryland State Plane NAD83. While DC's preferred projection is Maryland State Plane NAD83, we offer Web Mercator because it is widely used in the industry. How do I get the original GeoTIFF files as opposed to the compressed file? Yes of course! These files are quite large and can be several gigabytes of data. You will need to provide an external storage device such as a flash drive. Please reach out to DC GIS at dcgis@dc.gov so that we can work out the details. Note that the 2007 and 2011 images are only available as map services because they are licensed. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Template Foundation Data
description:
Foundation Data Template Address Points Address Points Featured Dataset Address Residential Units RESIDENTIAL UNITS Featured Dataset Points of Interest Points of Interest - MAR Aliases Featured Dataset Use this section to identify the foundational dataset. Include a sentence for how the District of Columbia government uses the foundational dataset. This section should be brief, but clearly state the dataset's collective value to DC. Foundational Data How to Use this Template This template is featuring data for Addressing. Hub pages are organized by Rows. Open Data DC hub pages should include rows for featuring the Data, Documentation, Tools and Development, Related Data and Common Questions. Add other sections as needed. Consider adding additional Top Links. To add Top Link, DELETE THIS CARD WHEN DONE. Dataset | 
		Documentation | 
		Tools and Development | 
		Related Data | 
		Common Questions Map Title Download More Data Documentation Before the MAR The format and quality of address information varied considerably across government enterprise systems, making it nearly impossible to identify all of the activity associated with a given address. Police reports recorded by MPD likely contained different addressing formats than drivers licenses at the DMV. Address anomalies, which do not fit logically into the DC address grid, were never tracked or accounted for. We have all seen these types of locations such as even numbered addresses incorrectly found on odd side of streets. Benefits of MAR Now, addressing standards are built in. They define the valid components of DC addresses (Address Number, Street Name, Street Type, Quadrant), including their correct formatting and spelling. It also includes related datasets for intersections, blocks and points of interest for prominent locations. The data was assembled from years of research of more than 20 address databases, like the US Postal Service, and it continues to be updated daily. This allows District agencies to more easily compare address information across all databases. For example, the 911 call center uses the exact same addressing system as the Department of Energy & Environment's storm water management teams. Tools and Development Quick Lookup The District created a nice, easy to use, website where anyone can search for a single address or square suffix lot. Just use one of our standard methods to get quick information. What Ward are you located in? What is your police district? What else? Desktop Geocoder The MAR Geocoder is a desktop application that employs web services to assign a location in the form of geographic coordinates. Please note, this application is no longer supported. This means that although the geocoder is still available and generally continues to work for some users, we are no longer devoting resources to support bug fixes nor enhancements. Web Services The MAR 2 API and web services provide a variety of methods to perform geocoding and address verification. Developers can create single address lookup or batch processing through the MAR. The MAR 2 API provides RESTful services with json outputs while the Legacy MAR web services use SOAP services with xml and json outputs. Search Addresses Batch Geocoding Reverse Geocoding Find Zones MAR 2 APIAllows users to search for addresses, place names, blocks and intersections within the DC boundary. MAR 2 APIThe preferred method for the bulk geocoding of addresses over cycling through and locating each address in a list. MAR 2 APIUse latitude and longitude coordinates to reverse lookup nearby addresses and the zones they are contained by. MAR 2 APIGet information regarding associated boundaries like ANC, police district, census tract, and Ward. Legacy MAR Legacy MAR Location Verifier Get DC Address Verify with String Get Street Name findLocationA catch all location query operation including DC addresses, intersections, blocks, AID, and place names. Variables: str - query string; f - json or xml. getDCAddressesAccepts a string (minimum four characters numbers or letters) and return all DC addresses that starts with the string. Variables: str - query string; f - json or xml. verifyDCAddressThrouStringUses concatenated DC address and returns information matching the given string. Variables: Address - concatenated DC address string; f - json or xml. getDCStreetNamesStreets in quad. Refine with start characters of street's name. Variables: quad - NE, NW, SE, SW; initialetters - string of character results begin with; f - json or xml. Relate with Other Datasets It's easy to relate the MAR with datasets across DC government. The MAR is stored in an Oracle enterprise relational database with over 20 unique tables and linked to the Department of Transportation's street spatial database. Look for these common unique identifiers to relate with many of the datasets offered in Open Data DC. Use the desktop geocoder to assign ADDRESS_ID to your data and link up to the property layers below. Title Title Title Title Sentence describing the content being featured. Sentence describing the content being featured. Sentence describing the content being featured. Sentence describing the content being featured. Download More Data Common Questions Question 1 Answer Question 2 Answer Question 3 Answer Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Roadway Centerlines
description:
Roadway Centerlines Roadway Block Roadway Block Local Roadway Blocks Roadway Block Roadway Block Blocks with PCI Score Above 80 Roadway Block Roadway Block Average Annual Daily Traffic Count The District's Department of Transportation (DDOT) maintains centerline-based roadway data for all roads and alleys open to traffic within the District of Columbia. In recent years, the District has improved its centerline data offerings to support a broad array of analyses and information sharing. Read below to learn more about what's available and what's coming soon. Foundational Data Dataset | 
		Documentation | 
		Bike Infrastructure | 
		Roadway Characteristics | 
		Highway Performance & Classification | 
		Tools and Development | 
		Common Questions Find More Roadway Data Documentation Making Roadway Data Better Centerline data has traditionally contained only information about the street itself. This is perfect for a lot of basic mapping tasks but problematic if you also need to know about the bike lanes or traffic volumes on the street. If you require an integrated view of data beyond what comes with the centerline data, an analysis is required combine these data into a unified dataset. The "All-in-one" roadway datasets below have been built to remove that burden. DC government has completely rebuilt its centerline datasets with two goals in mind: Choose Your Segmentation "Flavor" Data analysts at DDOT are "chopping up," (segmenting) the roadway in a variety of styles to support a broad array of analyses. Whether you are a GIS analyst, performance analyst or one of our public users, there are wide ranges of potential uses: Whatever the analytical need, these segmentations should cover a majority of use cases: Roadway Block Roadway SubBlock Roadway Blockface Intersection Approach A block begins at a street-to-street intersection and ends at the next street-to-street intersection.  Blocks are a common way in which to organize and relate work. Although driveways or alleys may intersect streets, the Block segmentation requires that the segment remain unbroken. Represents the full extent of the DC centerline network & contains every roadway type in DC roadway system. It is the finest-grained, 'base' segment from which all other segmentation patterns can be constructed (including Blocks). It is the original source of the DDOT Street Centerlines data. Unbroken sections of the curb. It can be made up of several subblocks, or one subblock. There are blockfaces on both sides of the road, each dependent on an unbroken length of curb. Blockfaceswill be the future home of parking zone summaries (in Development). Intersection Approach Segments are short segments of the route that approach an intersection - a short section of the road leading up to an intersection. Its purpose is to provide the network direction flow to the intersection point which may be important in analyses. Bike Infrastructure Pennsylvania Avenue Bike Lanes Pennsylvania Avenue Bike Lanes Contained within both Block and SubBlock segmentations are very detailed information about the bike infrastructure in DC. Conventional Bike Lanes are typically 5-feet wide with a bicycle symbol and arrow in the direction of travel with no physical separation to the adjacent parking and/or travel lane. Protected Bike Lanes are dedicated space for bicycling that is physically separated from automobile parking or traffic with posts, curbs or other type of vertical barrier. There are a total of 1,252 blocks in DC with a bike lane. Conventional Bike Lanes Total Bike Lanes Protected, Buffered Bike Lanes 73.7 miles 90.7 miles 17 miles Source: Roadway SubBlocks Source: Roadway SubBlocks Source: Roadway SubBlocks Roadway Characteristics There are potentially millions of different roadway configurations. DDOT's roadway segmentations capture an amazing amount of detail and provide useful summaries on over 50 different roadway characteristics: The Roadway Blocks dataset is packed with interesting roadway characteristics. These are just a few. Downtown DC Intersection Downtown DC Intersection Highway Performance and Classification In addition to configurations, the LRS now consolidates performance metrics such as annual average daily traffic volume, international roughness indexes and pavement condition indexes. Find both Federal and DC government classifications for road types or whether a particular segment is a DDOT snow plow route. The Roadway Blocks dataset is packed with interesting roadway characteristics. These are just a few. Tools and Development MAR Web Services The MAR API and Web Services provide a variety of methods to perform geocoding and address verification. Developers can create single address lookup or batch processing through the MAR. The MAR 2 API provides RESTful services with json outputs while the Legacy MAR uses SOAP services with xml and json outputs. Common Questions What is LRS? All of the data mentioned above comes from DDOT's Linear Referencing System (or LRS).  This is an enterprise system which helps consolidate and manage each GIS centerline and the roadway characteristics related to them. Read more here. What is Cross-section data? DDOT has captured the cross-sectional data for every roadway in DC.  It's extremely detailed and is fast becoming one of the key roadway analysis datasets.   Nearly half of the Roadway segmentation attributes come from summarizations of cross-section data. Read more here. What happens to the historic street centerline datasets? For over 20 years, the District has maintained and published centerline data in a variety of (now) legacy systems. While these datasets contained good information, the maintenance and publishing these data were extremely time-consuming and difficult.  These challenges led us to implement the new system we have today. Below are datasets that previously published from older systems, but can now be found in the new data, as follows: SubBlock Block SubBlock SubBlock Block SubBlock Intersection Block Intersection For all intersections regardless of road type, use Subblock Intersection For street-to-street intersections, use Block Intersection Block Block Block Block SubBlock Block SubBlock Block Block Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: DC COVID-19 Shelter Vaccine Summary
description: This dataset covers 3 main metrics; the number of people who have received at least one shot at a DHS event, the number of people who have received doses by role (client vs. staff), and the percentage of selected shelter populations that are partially or fully vaccinated.

title: Moving Violations Issued in March 2021
description: Moving citation locations in the District of Columbia. The Vision Zero data contained in this layer pertain to moving violations issued by the District of Columbia's Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and partner agencies with the authority. For example, DC's enforcement camera program cites speeders, blocking the box, and other moving offenses.. Moving violation locations are summarized ticket counts based on time of day, week of year, year, and category of violation.Data was originally downloaded from the District Department of Motor Vehicle's eTIMS meter work order management system. Data was exported into DDOT’s SQL server, where the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) geocoded citation data to the street segment level. Data was then visualized using the street segment centroid coordinates.

title: Parking Violations Issued in March 2021
description: Parking citation locations in the District of Columbia. The Vision Zero data contained in this layer pertain to parking violations issued by the District of Columbia's Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and partner agencies with the authority. For example, the District Department of Transportation's (DDOT) traffic control officers write parking violations to prevent congestion through enforcement and control at intersections.Parking violation locations are summarized ticket counts based on time of day, week of year, year, and category of violation.Data was originally downloaded from the District Department of Motor Vehicle's eTIMS meter work order management system. Data was exported into DDOT’s SQL server, where the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) geocoded citation data to the street segment level. Data was then visualized using the street segment centroid coordinates.

title: 2019 Traffic Volume
description: Traffic volume of Roadway Blocks. The dataset contains traffic volume data, created as part of the District of Columbia, Department of Transportation (DDOT) Roads and Highways database. A database provided by the District of Columbia, Department of Transportation identified traffic volume. Count data is collected (both direction) at pre-selected locations on Highway Performance Monitoring System (HPMS) Sections on a three-year cycle. These counts are converted to Annual Average Daily Traffic (AADT).

title: Public Lands
description:
Public Lands in DC District Government Land (Owned, Operated, and or managed) District Land District Government Property Lots Reservation Boundaries Reservations Reservation Boundaries Tax Exempt Properties TAX EXEMPT PROPERTY (RPTA) Tax Exempt Properties Government property is sometimes gifted by private entities, acquired, developed, and transferred in title or right of use between federal government and the District of Columbia. Recently, the Public Lands Act permits the District and the National Park Service (NPS) to enter into joint management agreements for sustainable maintenance and operation of Parks in the City. The District Owned, Operated, Managed Properties dataset below is a subset of the Common Ownership Lots (city-wide) and contains both private and public land. Foundational Data Dataset | 
		Documentation | 
		Tools and Development | 
		Related Data | 
		Common Questions DC Public Lands Finder Where are Government Properties? District Government Land (Owned, Operated, and or managed) Frequently updated as transactions occur. Our primary dataset for government related properties to be used by many DC Government agencies, private companies and the public. It supports the daily business process of District agencies that originate and manage land records. Transfers of Jurisdiction (TOJ) are also in this layer. Find More Data Documentation Federal vs District The Federal and District Government transfer properties in title, right of use, conveyances, and condemnation, known as Transfers of Jurisdiction (TOJ). The transfers involve all lot types and the reservation which was the original transfer may now have superseding lots. These records can be queried from the NARRATIVE field using a "like" statement for “TOJ”. It can also be found and queried in the District owned layer’s COMMENT field. Benefits of this Dataset The Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) has created a centralized map viewer, Public Lands in DC, that can be consumed by other web products with mapping capability or within web pages. It is considered the best master list of District assets and TOJs where interested parties have one place to view and update property data. Also, properties can be reviewed for compliance with various city ordinances. Two recent on-going efforts include, research and capture of all TOJ’s recorded in Office of Surveyor and creating highway plan and public easement layers. District Agency Coordination The Office of Tax and Revenue's Real Property Tax Administration is responsible for property assessments, ownership and address changes, tax billings, tax relief program administration, and land recordation for real property in the District of Columbia. The District’s assets, in coordination with RPTA, could be broken into four groups to better manage information, track developed properties and future acquisitions. Below are some, but not all, agencies involved with a sampling of related datasets. Development Deputy Mayor for Planning and Economic Development Deputy Mayor for Planning and Economic Development Department of Housing and Community Development Department of Housing and Community Development DC Housing Authority DC Housing Authority Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs Infrastructure District Department of Transportation District Department of Transportation Department of Parks and Recreation Department of Parks and Recreation DC Public Schools DC Public Schools Office of the Chief Technology Officer Office of the Chief Technology Officer Insurance Department of Insurance Securities and Banking Department of Insurance Securities and Banking Department of Employment Services Department of Employment Services Department of General Services Department of General Services Office of Risk Management Office of Risk Management Operations Metropolitan Police Department Metropolitan Police Department Department of Human Services Department of Human Services DC Health DC Health Department of Public Works Department of Public Works Tools and Development DC Owned, Operated, Managed A map showing District of Columbia government related properties (owned, operated, and or managed) to be used by many DC Government agencies, private companies and the public. It supports the daily business process of District agencies that originate and manage land records. Transfers of Jurisdiction (TOJ) are also in this layer. This map should not be considered comprehensive as District agencies continuously work to update properties as transactions occur. DC Real Property Finder A map designed to help residents, visitors and other property industry professionals identify the numerous geographies for federal lands, reservations, DC lands, personal property and more. Use this app to query assessment values and lot dimensions. The District's Vector Property Mapping (VPM) project works daily to capture property lot transactions so that city planners, business development leaders and residents stay current. Relate with Other Datasets For information about City-wide property data, please visit Property Lots in DC. Property or parcel data is a critical layer to any city or statewide data holdings. In our city's complex urban environment, this includes numerous geographies that identify federal government lands, reservations, District lands, personal property and so much more. Common Ownership Lots Considered a primary data set to begin working with. This polygon layer is built from the various lot types in the District. The common ownership dataset is conflated by Square, Suffix and Lot to include: Air Rights, Record, Parcel, Tax and Reservation lots. Some Parcels and Reservations fall outside of a Square’s boundary.  It does NOT include condominiums. Refer to the Condo Relate Table and Condo Approval Lot data. Common Questions How do District agencies collaborate to update public lands data? District of Columbia agencies continuously work to update properties as transactions occur however recognize opportunities for improvement. The recent Public Lands Act shows how coordination may improve the District’s ability to enter into more cooperative management agreements with the National Park Service. Franklin Park is an example. It is not a transfer of any sort but is a tool that the District and the NPS can utilize in efforts to co-manage parks in the city. The General Services Administration (GSA) would be another participating Federal Agency. How complete is the District Government Lands (Owned, Operated or Managed) data? It should not be considered comprehensive and there are opportunities for improvement. The District Owned, Operated, Managed Properties can be compared with data in Archibus, CARSS, ITS and is a consolidated layer of all District properties/assets and some locations managed by DGS portfolio division. Quarterly updates may make the most sense to keep the information as up-to-date some District Agencies sell the property once developed. There are additional features not related to Property Lots, have no Square Suffix Lot (SSL) and part of the Right-of-Way. 16th street medians and DPW Mowing locations are two examples. Below are some recommendations for all to be on the same page moving forward. These are designed to encourage policy and business processes to help keep data authoritative for the District's Property/Assets Management Team and Federal Interest. Where can I find information for properties, city-wide? For information about City-wide property data, please visit Property Lots in DC. Property or parcel data is a critical layer to any city or statewide data holdings. In our city's complex urban environment, this includes numerous geographies that identify federal government lands, reservations, District lands, personal property and so much more. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Connect Web Services
description:
Web Map & Data Services The District of Columbia's Open Data DC site a variety of web services for you to integrate into applications and desktop tools. Use these spatial and tabular based web services to save time and avoid the uncertainty of having current property and addressing data. Developer Guide Web Map Services | 
		MAR Web Services | 
		Property Web Services | 
		Best Practices | 
		Common Questions Web Map Services ArcGIS REST APIs You don't need specialized GIS software to consume DC's map services. They are easily accessed within web browsers or custom applications. The data layers you see individually in Open Data DC, are also published as a ArcGIS REST API endpoints. We do our best to organize them into themes or initiatives. Get Started To successfully use the ArcGIS REST API, you must understand how to construct a URL and interpret the response. All resources and operations exposed by the ArcGIS Services portion of the REST API are accessible through a hierarchy of endpoints for each GIS service published within DC's ArcGIS Server. Using Google Maps JS API Web Map Using Google Maps JS API Using Mapbox JS and JQuery Web Map Using Mapbox Use in Multiple Platforms Build it once and use it multiple ways. All the REST endpoints can be used across platforms. This Nearest Bike Share map using Mapbox JS and JQuery is an example of the same Capital Bike Share layer in ArcGIS.com. Resources ArcGIS REST API Follow step-by-step instructions to learn how to build applications with location services and use tools to prepare content and data for your applications. Tableau Dev Tools This article describes how to connect Tableau to an Esri ArcGIS Server and set up the data source. The connector also supports connections via GeoService API. Common Questions What geographic projection are DC's map services in? Most map services are projected in Web Mercator, such as those highlighted on this page. However, there are a few that are projected in Maryland State Plane NAD83. While DC's preferred projection is Maryland State Plane NAD83, we offer Web Mercator because it is widely used in the industry. Is there a place where I can look up a single address quickly? Use the DC MAR API sample viewer to perform single address, intersection, block or place name search. Here you can find details such as the Ward, Census Tract and Police District a location falls in. There is more! In most searches you will also have the option to view a preview map. What if the location services do not find an address I know exists? We have an online form where you may submit said location for review; however, it needs to meet probable criteria. Start by searching in the Master Address Repository. For example, if you search for  296 I Street SE you’ll find this address does not exist AND an web form link will appear at the bottom of the page. This address is possible since there is a 200 block of I Street SE. A search for 10096 I Street SE is not possible; there is no 10000 block of I Street SE and therefore no web link will appear. Do you have standards for using DC Web Services? Great question! We appreciate your consideration of this and ask that you read web services best practices for some tips. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Using APIs
description:
Using APIs Welcome application developers! We are very happy that you’re considering building with Open Data DC. Our goal is for this site to be your platform for developing apps around DC’s freely available, machine readable data. Open Data DC offers API access to users via dedicated URLs to each dataset. URLs in GeoJSON, GeoService and WMS point directly to our data sources and will return pure and timely data responses. Developer Guide Web Map Services | 
		MAR Web Services | 
		Property Web Services | 
		DC Starter Kit | 
		Best Practices | 
		Common Questions Let's get Started Or follow the quick start guide below... How much of an introduction do you need? An application programming interface (API) is an interface that defines interactions between multiple software applications or mixed hardware-software intermediaries. DC gov uses APIs as a means to serve data to its developer community. Learn More Find the Data Think of a keyword and enter it in the search box. Suggested keyword searches will appear as you begin typing. DC tags its layers with words we think will match your expected results. Field Attribute Preview Each data layer in the catalog comes with a brief description that helps give context. You will also see a publication date and boxes identifying attribute fields within the data. The Data tab at the top will show a preview of the table. Let's take a look at Building Energy Performance as an example. The Data tab will show you the preview table. Building Energy Performance Customize your API and try it out. Building Energy Performance API Explorer API Explorer The District of Columbia provides APIs and web services that empower you to create applications for fun, education, reporting, or business. The API Explorer tab at the top is where you can begin customizing your parameters and trying it out. Take a look at the Building Energy Performance API Explorer. Choose Your API In the details page of every data layer are two drop down menus. One of which contains a selection of pre-written URLs for the full dataset. Copy and paste your chosen API into your application, or send it to your development team. Resources DC Starter Kit Examples DC Starter Kit Use these APIs in any framework or tool that accepts GeoJSON, GeoService, CSV, OGC WMS, or Esri JSON. Use DC's open source starter kit to get a leg up or just some ideas. Explore live demonstrations that show you how to use our APIs and data with ArcGIS, Mapbox, D3, and Leaflet. See something missing in the above technologies? Comment at Welcome to Issues, or share in our Ways to Contribute. Common Questions Is there a bulk API available? All data is available for bulk download as CSV. Unfortunately, there is no easy way to chunk the CSV files for easier download. To get the direct link to the CSV, just copy the URL for the GeoJSON and replace .geojson with .csv. What is the difference between GeoJSON and Esri JSON? Both are valid JSON representations of earth-based geometries and the information attached to them. GeoJSON is more widely used in open source projects, while Esri JSON is mostly used in the widely distributed Esri products. However, it’s important to note that more and more Esri products are outputting GeoJSON, and accepting GeoJSON inputs. GeoJSON specifications is actually not bad reading for a document of this sort. But if you want something more entertaining, try Tom MacWright’s "More than you ever wanted to know about geojson." Here is the Esri JSON documentation: https://developers.arcgis.com/rest/. Esri provides some open source tools to work between the two formats: https://github.com/Esri/geojson-utils. While you’re there check out their other open source projects: https://github.com/Esri Do you have standards for using DC Web Services? Great question! We appreciate your consideration of this and ask that you read responsible use of our web services for some tips. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Building Energy Performance
description: This dataset is used by the Department of Energy & Environment (DOEE) as a disclosure of public and private building energy performance under the Building Energy Performance Standards (BEPS) Program.The BEPS Program was created by Title III of the Clean Energy DC Omnibus Act of 2018. The BEPS is a minimum threshold of energy performance that will be no lower than the local median ENERGY STAR score by property type (or equivalent metric). The standards were created to drive energy performance in existing buildings to help meet the energy and climate goals of the Sustainable DC plan — to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and energy consumption by 50% by 2032. DOEE established the first set of Standards on January 1, 2021. Standards will then be set every 6 years, creating BEPS Periods (BEPS Period 1, BEPS Period 2, etc.). The 2021 Building Energy Performance Standards and a Guide to the 2021 BEPS are available for viewing on DOEE’s website. To improve transparency and help building owners understand how their building performs relative to the BEPS, DOEE is publishing this BEPS Disclosure that compares a building’s benchmarking data with the BEPS and provides an estimate of the building’s distance from the standard and estimated performance requirement.Please note that this dataset is based on information currently available to DOEE using calendar year 2019 benchmarking data provided by the building owner. Some buildings are still being evaluated and therefore have been designated as “Under Review” in this dataset. Building owners that believe their 2019 calendar year data is incorrect should contact the Benchmarking Help Center (info.benchmark@dc.gov). Additionally, buildings that meet certain criteria may request a variance from the standards by submitting a variance request form on the DOEE website.

title: MAR Web Services
description:
MAR Web Services The MAR API and Web Services provide a variety of methods to perform geocoding and address verification. Developers can create single address lookup or batch processing through the MAR. The MAR 2 API provides RESTful services with json outputs while the Legacy MAR web services use SOAP services with xml and json outputs. This page provides information about all MAR services and examples of their usage. Developer Guide Web Map Services | 
		MAR Web Services | 
		Property Web Services | 
		Best Practices | 
		Common Questions Introducing MAR 2 API MAR 2 API Data Developer's Portal The Master Address Repository (MAR) 2 API is a new version of web services built on a modern code framework and provides output in modern data interchange format. It uses additional technology stacks to provide greater stability, enhanced response, and more flexibility. We encourage all our users to begin testing with MAR 2 API and of course build any new application with it, rather than Legacy MAR. The MAR 2 API is a modern .NET geocoding web service that utilizes ElasticSearch and an API Key to perform geocoding requests against MAR attributes and associated geometries. This portal provides developers with the ability to create user profiles, manage API Keys, review API guides, view code examples for MAR 2 API. The MAR 2 API is currently at version: 2.2 (September 2022) Data Developer's Portal Use these for all your new application development! Location Viewer Perform a single address lookup and display associated attributes. Batch Geocoding The new MAR Web Geocoder is a web browser-based tool used for geocoding locations, such as addresses, in Washington, DC. It operates by uploading Excel or CSV files to enrich your data with DC geographic characteristics such as Wards, Advisory Neighborhood Commissions, ownership lots, zip codes, longitude and latitude and more. It has built-in quality control checks that review your data for completeness and utilizes look-up tables for alternative names, abbreviations, and misspellings. The geocoder will append the information and deliver it as a downloadable Excel file – all adhering to the District’s addressing standards. For a full list of available geographic characteristics, read the MAR Web Geocoder user guide. Legacy MAR Web Services Legacy MAR web services have been around for many years. It is stable and has reached its maturity where we are no longer developing with it. Legacy MAR is not going away anytime soon, but we are asking developers to start testing their applications with MAR 2 API. Use MAR 2 API for all of your new applications! Example Web Service Operations Many tools exist for interfacing with Legacy MAR web services including Postman and SoapUI. We use Postman in some of the examples below.  It's an easy to use, free, and open source application with both web app and desktop application options. Below is a walk through of how to POST a request to the Legacy MAR web services followed by example operations. Initial set up To start open a new window and change the request type to POST by clicking GET and selecting POST from the drop down menu Click body and change it from form-data to raw. Click text and change it to XML (text/xml) A new window in the application Postman Initial Setup Customize your API and try it out. Building Energy Performance API Explorer Specifying Query Example Query Result Here's an example using the findLocation operation including the inputs and output text using 200 I St as our location string. Legacy MAR Operations Use: A catch all location query including DC addresses, intersections, blocks, AID, and place names.
		    
		    Variables:
		    str - query string; f - json or xml
		    
		    Url:
		    https://citizenatlas.dc.gov/newwebservices/locationverifier.asmx?op=findLocation2
		    
		    Body: getDCAddresses Use: Takes a string (minimum of four characters) and returns all DC addresses that begins with that string.
		    
		    Variables:
		    initialetter - string of letters that address starts withi>; f - jsonor xml
		    
		    Url:
		    https://citizenatlas.dc.gov/newwebservices/locationverifier.asmx?op=getDCAddresses2
		    
		    Body: verifyDCAddressThrouString Use: Uses concatenated DC address and returns information matching the given string.
		    
		    Variables:
		    Address - concatenated DC address string; f - json or xml
		    
		    Url:
		    https://citizenatlas.dc.gov/newwebservices/locationverifier.asmx?op=verifyDCAddressThrouString2
		    
		    Body: getDCStreetNames Use: Allows for calling of all streets within a quadrant. Further refinement can be done by giving the starting
		    characters of the street's name.
		    
		    Variables:
		    quad - NE, NW, SE, or SW; initialetters - string of character the result should begin with;
		    f - json or xml
		    
		    Url:
		    https://citizenatlas.dc.gov/newwebservices/locationverifier.asmx?op=getDCStreetNames2
		    
		    Body: RESTful Services The Legacy MAR web service can also be accessed using a RESTful style web service. Below are examples: Start with the URL below: Add the chosen service name followed by a question mark to the url, we will use the findLocation operation. The name of the operation can be found in the example url for each operation after "op=" add variables to the operation url putting a '&' between each. For findLocation this are str and f for which we will use 200 I St and json respectively. Common Questions When will Legacy MAR be taken offline? Can I look up a single address? Use the DC MAR API sample viewer to perform single address, intersection, block or place name search. Here you can find details such as the Ward, Census Tract and Police District a location falls in. There is more! In most searches you will also have the option to view a preview map. Are there more details on the MAR Web Services that I can read and learn? Yes, definitely. Download and read the MAR Web Services Documentation in PDF. Also visit our new Data Developer's Portal for details on MAR 2 API. Do you have standards for using Open Data DC web services? Great question! We appreciate your consideration of this and ask that you read our web services best practices for some tips. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Housing
description:
Mayor Bowser with Children DC government is making historic investments in affordable housing, home ownership programs and housing preservation. We're working to ensure that people of all backgrounds and at all stages of life can live and thrive in Washington, DC. We invite you to browse the data below, jump into government apps, create your own and share in our progress by engaging in some of our resident housing programs. ACS Demographic Characteristics DC ACS Demographic Characteristics of DC Total Housing Units ACS Housing Characteristics DC ACS Housing Characteristics of DC Total Housing Units Built (2014 or Later) Address Residential Units RESIDENTIAL UNITS Total Apartment Rental Units Economic Development | 
		Environment | 
		Housing | 
		Education | 
		Public Safety | 
		Transportation Total Children and Families Served in Foster Care The number of children and families served during the time period reported in foster care. The above dashboard shows the total number of children and families served cumulatively during the month. Specifically, it shows the total number of children served throughout the month, or all of the children who are still in foster care as of the last day of the month and any children who had exited foster care prior to the end of the month (and in foster care for at least one day). Source: Child and Family Services Dashboard. An exit occurs when Family Court issues a court order reunifying the child with their biological parent, finalizing a guardianship or adoption, or closing the child welfare case due to the child turning 21 years old. Source: Childe and Family Services Dashboard. More CFSA Dashboards Work with the Data We are working to connect you with all government data. Browse over a thousand datasets, download it as a file, analyze it or build apps. These are just a few datasets to explore. Search for more! Explore More Government Apps Housing Search Inclusionary Zoning Senior Services ANC and SMD Find accessible homes, affordable rentals and for-sale homes. Units reserved for households at specific income levels. Find services from DC Office of Aging designated Lead Agencies. Find your local elected Advisory Neighborhood Commission. More Apps and Maps Programs for Quality Housing In our most recent budgets, we continue to invest toward making Washington, DC more affordable for residents in all eight wards. Together, we are focused on keeping the District diverse, inclusive, and a place where all residents get a fair shot. Housing Counseling Residential Rehabilitation Roots to Roofs Rental Assistance Apply for assistance and information. Repairing threats to health and safety. Strength in our roots. Mitigating housing instability. Community-Based Non-Profit Organizations provide housing counseling services and training. Single Family Residential Rehabilitation (SFRRP) administers loans and/or grants for home
		                    repairs. Celebrate our residents who proudly have put their roots down here for generations – or want to in
		                    the future. The District has rental assistance programs and housing resources to help residents prevent eviction. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

Update the "View in Full Screen" URL to the application; this is especially important to users on mobile devices. Include the source: Organization. Background Before the MAR The format and quality of address information varied considerably across government enterprise systems, making it nearly impossible to identify all of the activity associated with a given address. Police reports recorded by MPD likely contained different addressing formats than drivers licenses at the DMV. Address anomalies, which do not fit logically into the DC address grid, were never tracked or accounted for. We have all seen these types of locations such as even numbered addresses incorrectly found on odd side of streets. title: Economic Development
description:
Mayor Bowser at Ribbon Cutting Washington, DC is a city that has a little something for everyone. In addition to the over 700,000 Washingtonians who call DC home, we also welcome tens of millions of visitors from around the world every year. Pride in DC is at an all-time high, and it’s easy to understand why. We invite you to browse the data below, jump into government apps, create your own and share in our progress by engaging in some of our economic development programs.
