title: Education
description:
Mayor Bowser with School Children The District's vision is for every student to feel loved, challenged, and prepared to positively influence society and thrive in life. We ensure that every school guarantees students reach their full potential through rigorous and joyful learning experiences provided in a nurturing environment. We invite you to browse the data below, jump into government apps, create your own and share in our progress by engaging in some of our educational programs. ACS Social Characteristics DC ACS Social Characteristics of DC Persons 25+ Years & Graduated High School ACS Social Characteristics DC ACS Social Characteristics of DC Households with Broadband Access ACS Social Characteristics DC ACS Social Characteristics of DC Persons 5+ Years Non-English Language Economic Development | 
		Environment | 
		Housing | 
		Education | 
		Public Safety | 
		Transportation Total Public School Audited Enrollment, 1990-2021 Total Public School Audited Enrollment, 1990-2021 Public school enrollment (DCPS and PCS) began increasing annually starting in 2009 after the passage of the Public Education Reform Amendment Act of 2007, granting mayoral control. Between 2008 and 2019, public school enrollment increased by 33%. SY2021-22 enrollment is preliminary reported enrollment. Final audited enrollment will be available in early 2022. Source: OSSE: Audit Enrollment. Total Public School Audited Enrollment by Sector, 2010-2021 Total Public School Audited Enrollment by Sector, 2010-2021 In 2020, a school year affected by the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, enrollment declined for the first time in over a decade to 93,747. Preliminary total public school enrollment for SY2021-22 was 93,843 students, a slight increase over the previous school year. Final audited enrollment will be released in early 2022. Source: OSSE: Audit Enrollment. Explore data from the U.S. Census Bureau through the Living Atlas. Work with the Data We are working to connect you with all government data. Browse over a thousand datasets, download it as a file, analyze it or build apps. These are just a few datasets to explore. Search for more! Explore More Government Apps School Profiles EdScape My School DC School Report Card Find detailed information about DCPS schools and programs. Five chapters of analysis by year, grade, neighborhood and sector. Find everything you need right here to learn, apply, and enroll. Are students prepared for success in classes and in their future careers? More Apps and Maps Thriving Education for All We will continue to invest in education so that all Washingtonians have the skills and knowledge they need to participate in our thriving economy. DC is staying focused with programs working to build inclusive learning environments. Thrive by Five My                    Child Care DC Career Prep Programs Learn24 Preparing our youngest learners. Early care and education at a glance. Intentional work experiences. Activities beyond the school day. Resources for parents and caretakers to navigate a range of early health and learning
		                    offerings. A place for parents to access meaningful information about child care in DC. Providing access to employment skills training, work-based learning, and internship
		                    opportunities. Network of afterschool and summer opportunities with access to quality educational and
		                    enrichment activities. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Environment
description:
Mayor Bowser at Anacostia River The District is using a combination of regulations, outreach, education, and incentive services to fulfill our mission. We work with residents, businesses, and institutions to promote environmentally responsible behavior leading to a more sustainable urban environment. We invite you to browse the data below, jump into government apps, create your own and share in our progress by engaging in some of our green programs. Best Management Practices DOEE Best Management Practices Total BMP on RiverSmart Homes Building Energy Benchmarks Building Energy Benchmarks Buildings in Compliance With Benchmark Reporting Adopt a Block Adopt A Block Total Adopt a Blocks by Citizens Economic Development | 
		Environment | 
		Housing | 
		Education | 
		Public Safety | 
		Transportation View in Full Screen Washington, DC stands apart from most other US cities when it comes to trees. Trees are considered essential and were included as an integral part of Pierre L'Enfant's original design. The L'Enfant Plan, drafted in 1791, reserved space in the public right-of-way exclusively for trees. Above are live statistics on preventive and routine tree maintenance as we inspect our tree inventory. Source: Urban Forestry Division. Work with the Data We are working to connect you with all government data. Browse over a thousand datasets, download it as a file, analyze it or build apps. These are just a few datasets to explore. Search for more! Explore More Government Apps Impervious Viewer Jump into these Government Apps Potential sites for Stormwater Retention Credits. More Apps and Maps Programs Making DC Green We are well on our way to making Washington, DC the healthiest, greenest, and most livable city in the nation. We’re thinking globally, acting locally, and building on our status as the world’s first LEED Platinum City. Get Riversmart! Stormwater Retention Credit Solar for All Energy Benchmarking For homes, communities, schools & more. Request an evaluation. Expand our solar capacity. Buildings over 50,000 gross square feet
		                    required. Incentives for property owners to install rain barrels, green roofs, rain gardens, pavers &
		                    more. Generate and sell credits to earn revenue for projects that reduce harmful stormwater runoff. Rooftop solar is the leading strategy for generating local, clean energy in the densely developed
		                    District. Tracking building energy against standard metrics and comparing its past performance and to its
		                    peers. Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

Mayor Bowser Riding DC Circulator We are committed to achieving an exceptional quality of life in the nation’s capital through more sustainable travel practices, safer streets and outstanding access to goods and services. title: Interagency Data Team
description:
Interagency Data Team The Interagency Data Team is a community of data analysts, or agency liaisons, who convene regularly with representation from DC agencies of all persuasions. DC government participants engage in discussions regarding the team’s core mission and priorities for a better kind of data culture – collection, application, sharing, classification and governance to name a few. The team is coordinated by the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), led by the Chief Data Officer (CDO), and directly supports the District of Columbia's Data Policy. The team is coordinated by the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), lead by the Chief Data Officer (CDO), and directly supports the District of Columbia's Data Policy.Role of the DC State Data CenterEnterprise Dataset Inventory, Lessons from Pilot AgenciesEnterprise Dataset Inventory, A General Counsel’s Perspective

title: Data Policy
description:
DC Data Policy Use this section to clearly state a measurable purpose for the program initiative with a citizen-centric approach. This section should be brief, but clearly state the program initiative's collective value to DC and what they will find below. Governance Purpose | 
		Scope | 
		Definitions | 
		Personnel and Roles | 
		Inventory and Classification | 
		Protection Standards Data Catalogs | 
		Interagency Data Sharing | 
		FOIA | 
		Legal Policy and Licensing | 
		Beneficiaries | 
		Effective Date | 
		Amendment Mayor's Order 2017-115 I. Purpose 1. This Order establishes a comprehensive data policy for the District government. 2. The data created and managed by the District government are valuable assets and are independent of the information systems in which the data reside. As such, the District government shall: 3. The greatest value from the District’s investment in data can only be realized when enterprise datasets are freely shared among District agencies, with federal and regional governments, and with the public to the fullest extent consistent with safety, privacy, and security. “Shared” means that enterprise datasets shall be: 4. By so sharing, the District can: 5. Because inappropriate disclosure of personal information and misuse of data for activities such as identity theft are significant concerns, the District’s data must also be managed and responsibly protected. To protect the safety, privacy, and security of residents, workforce members, clients, partners, stakeholders, visitors, and others, datasets requiring protection shall be identified and: II. Scope III. Definitions In this policy, the following definitions apply: Agency Data Officer (ADO) Means an employee, designated by an agency head, who, in coordination with the CDO, helps ensure that the agency is implementing this policy. Agency Information Security Officer (AISO) Means an employee designated by a District agency head or an OCTO employee, who is responsible for coordinating with the CISO to implement, manage, monitor, and report on cyber security for their assigned agency. Automated-anonymization-aggregation-generalization-redaction The process of creating a new derivative dataset that can be a lower-level dataset classification for more open distribution through a straightforward and repeatable automated processes. Chief Data Officer (CDO) Means the senior official reporting to the CTO who has overall responsibility for the District’s data governance processes, including the collection, creation, maintenance, documentation, dissemination, and archiving of high-quality, highly interoperable datasets. Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) Means the senior official reporting to the CTO who has overall responsibility for the District’s information security strategy and practices. Chief Performance Officer means the chief performance officer of the District government, a position within the Office of the City Administrator. Chief Technology Officer Means the agency director of OCTO. Creative Commons CC0 Public Domain Dedication (CC0) Means a license developed by Creative Commons that allows others to freely build on, enhance, and reuse the works for any purposes without restriction under copyright or database law. Creative Commons is a nonprofit international organization that creates standard copyright licenses for use by governments and other bodies to give the public permission to share and use creative work. Data Means a subset of information, whether quantitative or qualitative, that is regularly maintained by, created by or on behalf of, and owned or licensed by a public body in non-narrative, alphanumeric, or geospatial formats. Data are an asset independent of the systems or formats in which they reside. Dataset Means a collection of data organized or formatted in a specific or prescribed way. Typically, a dataset consists of one or more tables and is stored in a database or spreadsheet. Files of the following types are not datasets: text documents, emails, messages, videos, recordings, image files such as designs, diagrams, drawings, photographs, and scans, and hard-copy records. Dataset Classification Level 0, Open Refers to all enterprise datasets that do not fall within the definitions of level 1, 2, 3, or 4. For example, certificates of occupancy are determinations by the Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs (DCRA) that the use of a building, structure, or land in the District conforms to zoning regulations and building codes. This dataset would not be designated by DCRA as Level 1, 2, 3, or 4 and therefore would be considered Level 0. Moreover, any dataset regularly published in machine-readable format on opendata.dc.gov or another dc.gov website prior to this Order is considered “Level 0, Open” unless an agency makes a proactive determination to raise the classification. Level 1, Public Not Proactively Released Refers to a dataset that is not protected from public disclosure or subject to withholding under any law (including FOIA), regulation, or contract. Nevertheless, publication of the dataset on the public Internet and exposure to search engines would: Level 2, For District Government Use Refers to a dataset that the originating agency determines is subject to one or more FOIA exemptions, is not highly sensitive, and may be distributed within the District government without restriction by law, regulation, or contract. For example, OCTO licenses commercial data on businesses operating in the District. The license prohibits the public distribution of the data, and proprietary restrictions qualify as a FOIA exemption. Nevertheless, the data has widespread utility within the government, including for economic development and emergency management, and therefore would be classified as Level 2. Level 3, Confidential Refers to a dataset that the originating agency has determined is protected from disclosure by law, including FOIA, regulation, or contract and that is either highly sensitive or is lawfully, regulatorily, or contractually restricted from disclosure to other public bodies. Such datasets generally include datasets that contain data that qualifies for designation by a federal agency or District agency as: Level 4, Restricted Confidential Refers to datasets for which the originating agency has determined that unauthorized disclosure could potentially cause major damage or injury, including death, to residents, agency workforce members, clients, partners, stakeholders, or others identified in the information, or otherwise significantly impair the ability of the agency to perform its statutory functions. Includes any dataset designated by a federal agency at the level “Confidential” or higher under the federal government’s system for marking classified information. District of Columbia Internal Data Catalog (Internal Catalog) Means a District government intranet-accessible web portal that is centrally managed, hosted, and funded and has capabilities similar to the District of Columbia Open Data Catalog but which is open only to District government employees and which facilitates interagency data sharing. District of Columbia Open Data Catalog (Open Catalog) Means a publicly accessible web portal that helps members of the public find, understand, and utilize enterprise datasets. Districtwide Domain Tables Means database tables and services designated by the CDO that provide a standard source of values to be used across District information systems and data transformations. For example, the CDO could designate a table as containing the official list of agency names and abbreviations and promote use of the table by other systems. View Domain Tables. Enterprise Dataset Enterprise Dataset Inventory Means a listing of datasets of all public bodies, including each enterprise dataset’s designated classification level and justification for that designation and other limited metadata elements for each dataset. Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Means the Freedom of Information Act of 1976, effective March 25, 1977 (D.C. Law 1-96; D.C. Official Code § 2-531 et seq.). FOIA provides that any person has the right to request access to records. Under FOIA, all public bodies of the District government are required to disclose public records, except for those records, or portions of records, that are protected from disclosure by the exemptions found at D.C. Code Official § 2-534. Information Means all records, narrative and non-narrative, managed by the District. Metadata Means a description of an enterprise dataset, such as date of creation or last update; author, maintainer, or point of contact; a dictionary to support the correct interpretation of data; and documentation of methodology or business rules. Originating Agency Means the District agency that compiles and manages the dataset in its original form, or on whose behalf the compiling and management is done. Open Government Advisory Group (OGAG) Means a committee of District government employees and public representatives established by Mayor’s Order 2016-094, issued June 9, 2016, to provide advice on transparency, open data, and open government. Subjective Redaction Means the process of creating a derivative dataset at a lower-level classification for more open distribution through a process that require humans or artificial intelligence to review the dataset each time the dataset is requested. IV. Personnel and Roles A. Chief Information Security Officer The CTO shall appoint a CISO for the District government who has the full delegated authority of the CTO for all matters pertaining to information security for the District. The CISO shall be a full-time employee who, in alignment with his or her primary responsibilities, furthers implementation of and compliance with this policy by doing the following: B. Agency Information Security Officers Within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this Order, each public body shall designate an AISO. The AISO may be an existing employee who performs other functions. The AISO is assumed to be the public body’s information technology lead unless another employee is designated by the agency director. For smaller public bodies, an employee of OCTO shall, at the request of the agency director, serve as the public body’s AISO, and the agency director shall appoint an employee of the public body to serve as the public body’s liaison with the AISO. AISOs shall, in coordination with public body CIOs, the CISO, the CDO, and OCTO, assist with implementation of this policy by doing the following: C. Chief Data Officer The CTO shall appoint a CDO for the District government. The CDO shall be a full-time employee who, among his or her other responsibilities, furthers implementation of, and compliance with, this policy by doing the following: D. Agency Data Officer Within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this Order, each public body shall designate an ADO, who shall, in coordination with the public body CIO, the CISO, the AISO, the CDO, and OCTO, assist with implementation of this policy. The ADO may be an existing employee who performs other functions. In many cases, the ADO may be an analyst with a crosscutting view of the public body’s data, often an analyst who prepares performance data submissions for the Office of the City Administrator. In smaller public bodies, the ADO may be the public body’s information technology or communications lead. ADOs shall further implementation of, and compliance with, this policy by doing the following: For smaller agencies, OCTO shall, upon the request of the agency, assist the agency ADO in carrying out these functions. V. Enterprise Dataset Inventory, Classification & Prioritization 1. Public bodies shall inventory their enterprise datasets. 2. To establish the Districtwide enterprise dataset inventory, the following actions shall be taken: 3. As part of the annual dataset inventory and in coordination with public bodies, the CDO shall establish a process for assessing datasets or derivatives of datasets for future publication as Level 0, Open. That process shall include whether publication of a dataset: VI. Minimum Data Protection Standards The safety, privacy, and security of residents, agency workforce members, clients, partners, or anyone else identified in the datasets are paramount concerns. Public bodies shall work on an ongoing basis toward meeting the following dataset protection minimum standards: VII. Data Catalogs A. To facilitate data sharing, OCTO shall:1. Operate and continuously improve the District of Columbia Open Data Catalog and the District of Columbia Internal Data Catalog. At a minimum, the catalogs shall facilitate: B. To facilitate data sharing, public bodies shall: VIII. Streamlined Processes for Interagency Data Sharing To lower the cost and increase the speed of the intra-District sharing of datasets classified as Level 2 or Level 1, the Chief Technology Officer, in coordination with the Office of the City Administrator, shall develop uniform data-sharing agreements. A public body shall not require another public body to enter into a data-sharing agreement other than the uniform data-sharing agreement in order to have access to view, utilize, or transfer Level 1 or Level 2, datasets, unless a different data-sharing agreement is approved by the City Administrator. IX. Nexus Between FOIA and Level 0, Open Datasets X. Level 0, Open, Data Legal Policy, And Licensing The following terms and conditions are established to facilitate the sharing of datasets: XI. No Third-Party Beneficiaries No individual or entity shall have any right, interest, or claim under this policy or be entitled to any benefit under or on account of this policy as a third-party beneficiary or otherwise. XII. Effective Date This Order shall become effective immediately. MURIEL BOWSER MAYOR ATTEST: _______________________________________ LAUREN C. VAUGHAN SECRETARY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA Amendment Mayor's Order 2018-050 By virtue of the authority vested in me as Mayor of the District of Columbia by section 422(6)
		and (11) of the District of Columbia Home Rule Act, approved December 24 1973,87 Stat. 790,

title: District of Columbia Data Policy
description: Mayor's Order 2017-115. District of Columbia Data Policy. Originating Agency: Office of the Mayor. A comprehensive data policy for the District of Columbia government. The data created and managed by the District government are valuable assets and are independent of the information systems in which the data reside.

title: District of Columbia Data Policy Amendment
description: Amendment. A comprehensive data policy for the District of Columbia government. The data created and managed by the District government are valuable assets and are independent of the information systems in which the data reside.

title: Open Data Handbook
description:
Open Data Handbook The open data handbook explains the process and steps OCTO undertakes when an agency submits an open dataset for publication. The handbook outlines dataset rules, documentation requirements, and policies to make data consistent and standardized. This applies to any dataset submitted for publication on the Open Data DC portal that is classified as Level 0: Open as defined in the District’s Data Policy. Governance Purpose | 
		Background | 
		Submission Process | 
		Maintenance | 
		Dataset Classification | 
		Related Content | 
		Full Document Purpose Accountability Provides transparency and accountability for DC’s data program. Process Allows stakeholders to understand the overall data curation process. Standardize Documents data policies, rules, and guidelines for open data consistency. This page summarizes the handbook published in December 2022. Read the full document for the complete process including metadata and data dictionary standards. An initial version, released in 2018, is available here. Background Data Submission Process Data Curation Summary Diagram The Data program works as a partner to an agency throughout the process. The communication between the teams is key as the data originator shares the meaning and structure of the data while OCTO ensures it is published and distributed as intended. The process provides an overall framework to promote consistency and standardization within data warehousing and GIS databases, depending on the type of data being provided. It provides a well-documented dataset that can be utilized by DC agencies or the public via direct database queries, downloads, or Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). DC’s data submission process involves five steps generally summarized below. Universal Request The program receives requests for data publication from multiple points of contact. The intake process is centralized using OCTOhelps ServiceNow IT Service Management platform.  Requests are received as Universal Requests (UR) and are assigned to the appropriate OCTO group. Data originators are directed to octohelps.dc.gov to initiate the process with basic information on the dataset under the GIS and Data Services category. Preparation After completing a universal request, the data analyst will work with the data originator to build a Data Curation Packet (DCP). This is maintained by the data analyst, but useful in conveying all necessary components below: Consultation The data analyst will thoroughly review the data curation packet’s information, specifications, requirements, and sample data before initiating the third step – consultation. First, the data discovery form is proof-read for completion and comprehension for a non-technical audience. Complex narratives should be moved to supplemental documentation. Then, the data dictionary is evaluated against the data sample to ensure descriptions, aliases, and coded domain values are present. Next, the data sample is evaluated against the program’s dataset rules. If applicable, the data mapping document is reviewed to ensure proper transformations are applied. The data analyst will then request a consultation and deliver feedback. Together they review the quality of the data, obtain approvals if needed, finalize submission requirements, and finish documentation. The data analyst will confirm the data meets the classification Level 0: Open as defined by the DC Data Policy. If there is uncertainty in classification, then the originator is referred to the agency’s General Counsel. Often the consultation can determine that more work is needed by the agency before the dataset can move to curation. Curation This step involves building the database schema, tables, views, indexes, and other related entities.  This process begins in lower environments to ensure accuracy and success before moving to production. Furthermore, data analysts will, Publication The datasets are published to production databases where they can be accessed more broadly by the DC government GIS and business intelligence user-base. Public datasets are then published as map services on the District’s ArcGIS Server stack. Map services allow cloud and desktop applications to access the most recent dataset via ArcGIS REST endpoints and on Open Data DC as commonly used open formats via APIs, including, GeoJSON, OGS WMS, and GeoServices. All map services are published using ArcGIS Pro. To publish a map service, Once the dataset is published on ArcGIS Server and Open Data DC, this completes the submission process. Note: raster datasets such as orthophotography and LiDAR are published on the District's ArcGIS Image Server at https://imagery.dcgis.dc.gov/dcgis/rest/services. These datasets undergo unique curation processes in coordination with licensed vendors. Maintenance A periodic review of published datasets will occur as structure changes and technology enhancements. The review will go through the same process as a new universal request using information from the initial request. Published datasets may also become obsolete or dated, at which point archiving the dataset will be an option. The Data program will review archiving options with the data originator. If authorized, the dataset will be included in the Data program’s archive with a note added to the metadata. Dataset Classification Datasets published on Open Data DC must adhere to the Dataset Classification standards provided in the DC Data Policy. Specifically, a dataset that would otherwise meet the definitions of Level 1, 2, 3, or 4 data cannot be published via Open Data DC. An agency must make a proactive determination to prepare a dataset for public release. This would involve ensuring that none of the elements in the dataset would not collectively classify it as Level 1, 2, 3, or 4. The modification to datasets classified at Level 1, 2, 3, or 4 must remove all elements that fall under the definition of those dataset classification levels to make them Level 0, Open.  This can be achieved by entirely removing those data elements which make them above Level 0 or using data anonymization tools that allow for the data elements to be modified of changed via techniques such as masking or applied algorithms for which the data cannot be reconstituted or used in coordination with other datasets to restore it to its previous classification levels. These changes should be made in agreement with agency general counsel. Changes in elements contained in a dataset previously classified according to the Dataset Classification section of the DC Data Policy would require it undergo classification once more. View all dataset classification definitions here. Related Content Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Open Data Handbook Curation Diagram
description: Open Data Handbook Curation Detailed Diagram. DC’s data submission process involves four steps as depicted in this diagram. Overall, the data analysts guide the data owner and other analysts as needed to run the data through the submission process, with different groups leading each part (see all caps in diagram above).  Their application occurs in a unified database infrastructure consisting of a data warehouse and geospatial database.  While there are specific processes and guidelines for each database, they share an overall setting where consistency and standardization are promoted and supported for their individual data curation processes.

title: Open Data Handbook 2018
description: The Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), within the District of Columbia (DC) government, manages the District’s data program. This includes open data, business intelligence, data curation, and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). The open data handbook explains the process and steps the OCTO data program undertakes when an agency submits an open dataset. More importantly, the handbook documents dataset rules, metadata requirements, and policies to make data consistent and standardized. This applies to any dataset submitted for publication on DC’s open data portal.

title: Moving Violations Issued in April 2021
description: Moving citation locations in the District of Columbia. The Vision Zero data contained in this layer pertain to moving violations issued by the District of Columbia's Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and partner agencies with the authority. For example, DC's enforcement camera program cites speeders, blocking the box, and other moving offenses.. Moving violation locations are summarized ticket counts based on time of day, week of year, year, and category of violation.Data was originally downloaded from the District Department of Motor Vehicle's eTIMS meter work order management system. Data was exported into DDOT’s SQL server, where the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) geocoded citation data to the street segment level. Data was then visualized using the street segment centroid coordinates.

title: Parking Violations Issued in April 2021
description: Parking citation locations in the District of Columbia. The Vision Zero data contained in this layer pertain to parking violations issued by the District of Columbia's Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and partner agencies with the authority. For example, the District Department of Transportation's (DDOT) traffic control officers write parking violations to prevent congestion through enforcement and control at intersections.Parking violation locations are summarized ticket counts based on time of day, week of year, year, and category of violation.Data was originally downloaded from the District Department of Motor Vehicle's eTIMS meter work order management system. Data was exported into DDOT’s SQL server, where the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) geocoded citation data to the street segment level. Data was then visualized using the street segment centroid coordinates.

title: Chief Data Officer Annual Report 2018
description:
The CDO annual report documents accomplishments and the Enterprise Dataset Inventory results of the previous calendar year. It assess current progress and shares the District's progress with Open Data and the Data Policy. Mayor Bowser is “making our local government one of the most accessible systems in the country.” To that end, the Mayor issued Executive Order 2017-115, District of Columbia Data Policy, on April 27, 2017, with the stated goal of leading the District of Columbia government toward more open and efficient use and sharing of government data.
		The policy established these principles acknowledging the value of data to the District and the inherent need to balance openness with other concerns:Data are valuable assets independent of the information systems in which the data reside.The greatest value from those assets is realized when freely shared to the extent consistent with the protection of safety, privacy, and security.

title: Chief Data Officer Annual Report 2019
description: The CDO annual report documents accomplishments and the Enterprise Dataset Inventory results of the previous calendar year. It assess current progress and shares the District's progress with Open Data and the Data Policy. Since last year’s report, I was privileged to spend most of my work time serving as the Interim Chief Technology Officer of the District of Columbia, as well as Chief Data Officer. OCTO is a unique and special agency, with a breadth of responsibility that runs from complex statewide applications for sophisticated customers like the Department of Motor Vehicles to hyper-local hands-on tech support in the public schools. That acknowledged, I’d like to thank Mayor Muriel Bowser for trusting me to run the agency that has shaped much of my career, and thanks also to our newly appointed CTO, Lindsey Parker, for diving right into data and open government efforts and supporting our team.

title: Chief Data Officer Annual Report 2020
description:
The CDO annual report documents accomplishments and the Enterprise Dataset Inventory results of the previous calendar year. It assess current progress and shares the District's progress with Open Data and the Data Policy. This is the District of Columbia’s Chief Data Officer’s Annual Report produced within the of context the draft strategic plan for the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO).
		The Draft Technology Strategic Plan for DC: Unleashing the Possible, though still a draft, is providing direction and clarity to the agency, the District government, and the Chief Data Officer (CDO) program. OCTO is building on a strong foundation and expanding services to help DC Government by providing agencies opportunities to share, store and analyze data to uncover insights to improve services for residents; and the development of this plan has brought renewed energy and mission to OCTO, thus “unleashing the possible.”

title: Families First DC Communities
description: Families First DC will provide grants to establish community-based organizations that will drive the placed-based services based upon the needs by launching Family Success Centers in five communities in Ward 7 and five in Ward 8. These focused areas were selected based on social determinants of health data, violence prevention priority areas, and substantiated reports on child abuse and neglect.

title: Enterprise Dataset Inventory
description:
Enterprise Dataset Inventory Enterprise Dataset Inventory Enterprise Dataset Inventory Total Datasets in 2023 Enterprise Dataset Inventory Level 0 Not on Open Data DC Level 0 Data Not On Opendata Portal Level 0, Not on Open Data DC Cumulative FOIA Report FY 2022 Cumulative FOIA Report Data FY2022 Total FOIA Requests Received In the District, data governance is established by Mayor's Order 2017-115, known as the Data Policy. The Mayor has directed that "data are valuable assets independent of the information systems in which the data reside. The District government realizes the greatest value from those assets is realized when freely shared to the extent consistent with the protection of safety, privacy, and security." DC government maintains an inventory of its enterprise datasets and classifies the enterprise datasets by level of sensitivity. Program Initiative Background | 
		Datasets | 
		Apps & Maps | 
		CDO Reports Enterprise Dataset Inventory 2023 Enterprise Dataset Inventory 2023 How did agencies classify datasets in 2023? Level 0, Open Refers to all enterprise datasets that do not fall within the definitions of level 1, 2, 3, or 4. For example, certificates of occupancy are determinations by the Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs (DCRA) that the use of a building, structure, or land in the District conforms to zoning regulations and building codes. This dataset would not be designated by DCRA as Level 1, 2, 3, or 4 and therefore would be considered Level 0. Moreover, any dataset regularly published in machine-readable format on opendata.dc.gov or another dc.gov website prior to this Order is considered “Level 0, Open” unless an agency makes a proactive determination to raise the classification. The DC Data Policy also lays out a dataset classification system to help determine which enterprise datasets should be open to the public and which should be closed to protect privacy, safety, and security. Classifications were submitted by each Agency Data Officer and approved by a General Counsel. In 2023, agencies tagged 752 datasets as containing Personally Identifiable Information (PII). Read more about classification. In 2023, agencies were asked to review previous datasets and mark whether they included race or ethnicity characteristics. Background What is "Open by Default?" The District's data policy states that “enterprise datasets shall be open by default, meaning their existence will be publicly acknowledged, and further, if enterprise datasets are not shared, an explanation for restricting access will be publicly provided.” In other words, “open by default” means that although the District has many datasets that it cannot share, we should not have any that we will not inform the public of. Agency Participation The annual dataset inventory continues to show consistent participation from Mayoral and many independent agencies. The 2023 inventory recorded 2,204 enterprise datasets, up from 2,164 datasets in 2022. This year's inventory includes a restructuring of the Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs (DCRA), which ceased to exist as of October 1, 2022, and then split into two separate agencies - the Department of Buildings (DOB) and the Department of Licensing and Consumer Protection (DLCP). As a result, both DOB and DLCP only have datasets for FY 2023. Increased Participation The following agencies increased their inventories by the greatest percentage in 2023: Work with Data Current Inventory Past Inventories Analysis and Visualization Interactive Apps and Maps Which Agencies Participated? How Did Agencies Classify Enterprise Datasets? Which Agencies Retired Datasets? Reports and Studies Keep Up with Our Work Take an active interest in Open Data DC. Following us to get updates new events, data, and tools that you can use to help us achieve our goals.

title: Traffic Safety Input
description: DDOT is committed to making District streets safer for all roadway users while providing multimodal mobility and access for residents, visitors, and commercial users. A combination of trafﬁc control devices and trafﬁc calming measures can help meet both goals. DDOT has a full portfolio of proactive, data-based safety efforts, which can be reviewed at https://visionzero.dc.gov/pages/engineering. In addition, our Trafﬁc Safety Input (TSI) program provides a mechanism for DDOT to hear from residents on roadway segments and intersections where users have safety concerns.

title: 311 City Service Requests in 2021
description: Data provided here are from the DC's 311 service request center. They represent all service requests such as abandoned automobiles, parking meter repair and bulk trash pickup. Requests are received by the Office of Unified Communications (OUC) through the Mayor's Call Center (311), citizens web intake at https://311.dc.gov, electronic and US mail service or via other methods of communication. The Office of Unified Communications (OUC) oversees the designated call center for all 311 calls and for all District 911 calls. Please also visit the DC 311 Service Request Map which allows the public to see service requests in the last 30 days. Users can view requests by Ward within charts. Just set the area filter to select service requests. Click on a service request to view details.

title: DC Forest Action Plan
description:
DC State Forest Action Plan Assessment of Urban Forest Resources and Strategy Assessment of Urban Forest Resources and Strategy Learn more about: Forest conditions and trends Threats to forest lands and resources Priority issues and areas Urban Forest strategy Conditions and Trends Current Conditions Washington DC has many tracts of continuous forested area, providing opportunities for diverse ecosystems including Rock Creek Park, Palisades Parkway, the C&O Canal National Historical Park and Fort Dupont. Common DC wildlife includes bald eagles, bats, coyotes, deer, ducks, eastern box turtles, eastern cottontails, foxes, owls, woodchucks and more. Washington DC straddles two ecoregions, the Piedmont and the Southeast Plains ecoregion. The dominant native vegetation on most of the well-drained loamy soil of the Piedmont is deciduous forest, and the native vegetation for the Southeast Plains in the District is mostly hardwoods with some softwoods. Located at the confluence of two rivers, Washington DC is a subtropic climate zone characterized by hot, humid summers and cold winters. Between 1981 and 2019, Washington DC’s median annual rainfall was almost 40 inches, with May and July being the wettest months. Expected climate change With slow warming trends in the air and water, it is expected that storms, such as nor’easters, that are created by mixing of high and low temperature air, and hurricanes, that are formed by combining warm water and humid air, will increase in frequency and/or magnitude. Based on scenarios developed by the DOEE and using data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the USACE, water levels for the Potomac and Anacostia Rivers is expected to increase by 3.4 foot by 2080. This increase will put the District and many of its residents at greater risk for coastal flooding in the future. DOEE, using NOAA data, has projected that by the 2080s, the average summer temperature in Washington DC will be between 93- and 97-degrees Fahrenheit and the number of heat emergencies (days when the heat index reaches 95 degrees Fahrenheit or above) will increase to 40-75 days annually. The increase in heat and irregularities and changes in precipitation will put further stress on DC’s urban forest. Projected impacts of climate change on forests may lead to shifts in timing of budburst and flowering, changes in forest community structure and productivity (IPCC). Climate change may also result in increased disturbances such as pest outbreaks and extreme weather events, which may lead to mortality. Current State and Threats to the District’s Urban Forest DC's Urban Forest Washington DC’s urban forest is managed by the District’s Urban Forestry Division. The mission of UFD is to manage and increase the District's street trees to maintain healthy trees that provide improved air quality, increased groundwater retention that minimizes runoff and flooding, temperature moderation, aesthetics, and other benefits to the community. UFD does this by providing comprehensive urban forest management services across all public lands. Such services include tree planting, pruning, removal and inspection. In addition, UFD provides educational outreach and technology transfer to District residents regarding the benefits of urban trees, proper tree care techniques and other forest health-related information. This is all done with the goal of managing and increasing DC’s public trees and creating a healthy and robust tree canopy. Washington DC’s Urban Forestry Division is housed within the District’s Department of Transportation and is charged with managing the approximately 200,000 trees in the public space, which includes trees within public rights of way such as tree boxes, continuous planting strips, medians, and traffic circles. The Urban Forestry Division also provides stewardship for trees growing on other public lands, such as public parks, libraries, and schools. DC Urban Heat Islands Urban Forest Threats Washington DC is primarily an urban environment. The biggest threat to Washington DC’s forest are pressures associated with urban environments. Factors such as the urban heat island effect, limited and degraded soil volumes, and development can all contribute to the declining health of trees. This can include reduced growth, a shorter lifespan and increased susceptibility to pests. Pests and Pathogens One of the most persistent threats to the urban forest is non-native pests and pathogens. The unintentional introduction of these non-native species is typically a result of economic activity and may occur with nursery stock, produce or other similar products. The Asian longhorned beetle, emerald ash borer and redbay ambrosia beetle are all examples of non-native invasive forest pests. Foreign pests and pathogens can increase tree mortality and can cause canopy thinning or dieback, growth loss, defoliation, and decreased reproduction or regeneration. Climate change may exacerbate these impacts. Changes in seasonal temperature and an increase in severe weather events can impact trees’ development and survivability, making them more susceptible to both native and non-native pests and pathogens. Additionally, warming trends may accelerate insect development rate and their natural mobility may expand their impact on forest environments. Priority Issues Priority Issue 1: Expand, Preserve and Improve the Urban Forest Sub-issue 1: Increase Urban Tree Canopy across all Ownership In Washington, D.C. the Urban Forestry Division (UFD) is the governing body primarily responsible for managing the urban forest in the public space. They are charged with tasks such as planting, pruning, removing, and maintaining the health of the District’s tree canopy, all with the goal of helping the District reach its 40 percent tree canopy goal. They manage approximately 175,000 street trees as well as trees on DC parkland and recreational properties. According to land cover analyses performed with support from the US Forest Service, street trees make up ~9 percent of the District's overall tree canopy. Sub-issue 2: Protect and Improve Environmental Health The interconnectedness of the environment means that a healthy tree canopy supports the health of the overall environment and those living in it. In an urban setting, this is especially important because the air purification and water filtration that trees provide not only impacts local wildlife, but it also impacts the health of the city’s residents. Sub-issue 3: Expand Resiliency Across the District using Urban Forestry Urban Heat Island Effect
		Heat islands are described by the US EPA as urbanized areas that experience higher temperatures than outlying areas as a result of structures, such as buildings, roads and other infrastructure, absorbing and re-emitting the sun’s heat more than natural landscapes. It is referred to as the Urban Heat Island Effect (UHI) because it is prevalent in urban areas. There are five main strategies for combating the UHI: increasing tree and vegetative cover, installing green roofs, installing cool roofs, installing reflective or permeable pavements, and utilizing smart growth practices. Flooding/flood preventionTrees are the original green infrastructure and used in conjunction with other bioretention facilities are able to trap large amounts of stormwater. Using green infrastructure techniques and planting and maintaining trees can mitigate flooding in riparian zones, MS4 areas and 100- and 500-year floodplains. Mitigate Climate ChangeA 2015 i-Tree Ecosystem Analysis (i-Tree Eco) found that the District’s tree canopy provided the following benefits:● Pollution removal: 619 tons/year ($26.0 million/year)● Carbon storage: 649,000 tons ($46.2 million)● Carbon sequestration: 26,700 tons/year ($1.90 million/year)● Oxygen production: 42,700 tons/year ($0 /year)● Avoided runoff: 42,386,000 cubic feet/year ($2.82 million/year)● Building energy savings: $705 thousand/year● Avoided carbon emissions: $168 thousand/year● Structural values: $4.28 billion Sub-issue 4: Management for a More Resilient Forest Climate Adaptation
		Trees build resiliency in a city, but the urban forest itself must also be climate resilient. To create a forest that can withstand the inevitable impacts of climate change, two actions should be taken: new trees must be thoughtfully planted, putting the right tree in the right place, and proactive management to mitigate risk to residents and the forest at large. Pest Control, Disease Prevention
		The urban forest is productive as long as the trees remain healthy. Protecting trees from pests and disease maintains both a healthy canopy and a productive urban ecosystem. In some areas of Washington DC, streets are lined with even-aged tree cohorts, which may be limited to one species. These nicely canopied avenues are striking to observe and enjoyed by residents and visitors alike. However, such low diversity in species and age puts these areas at risk to potential introductions of non-native pests and pathogens. Urban Forest CompositionAs the climate continues to change, the Urban Forestry Division, as managers of the Districts urban forest, must adjust their tree planting and maintenance strategies to ensure that the forest is not just managed for the people, but for long term growth. More intense extreme heat days and strong weather events put significant strain on DC’s urban forest and in response UFD will limit planting of common trees such as sugar maple and emphasize planting of more resilient tree species, including the Shumard oak which is tolerant of heat and drought. Existing trees, such as the hackberry can stand up to the changing climate as it is tolerant of drought and other environmental stressors. Today, UFD uses more than 125 species and varieties. Diversifying tree species creates a more hardy tree canopy and increases the urban forest’s resiliency to pest and disease. Priority Issue 2: Cultivate an Urban Forest that is Equitable, Inclusive and Accessible Sub-issue 1: Build Urban and Community Forestry Program Capacity Sub-issue 2: Make Urban Forest Benefits Accessible As the “City of Trees”, Washington DC has an extensive urban forest. However, in a 2018 survey about the District’s urban forest 89 percent of respondents said that they think the District needs more trees and 56 percent specified street trees as an area that needs higher canopy. The urban forest provides many different benefits that support a community’s social, environmental, and economic wellbeing. However, limited access to the urban forest can prevent neighborhoods from experiencing these benefits. Priority Issue 3: Multi-State Priority Areas Sub-Issue 1: Mid-Atlantic Shared Stewardship Sub-issue 2: Interjurisdictional Coordination in Urban Forestry Urban forestry is a vital component to livable, well-planned communities, which are also important to open space conservation. An urban tree canopy reduces stormwater runoff, particularly during the smaller rains that are most frequent and often carry high concentrations of pollutants. Based on current models, trees that overlap impervious areas tend to have greater ability to mitigate stormwater. Urban tree canopy also has the side benefit of decreasing air temperatures to improve air quality. Despite being in different forestry regions, the different jurisdictions within the DC metropolitan area works closely to coordinate environmental and forestry activity. The District’s Urban Forestry Division (UFD) works collaboratively with District, local, and regional organizations to create consistency and agreement in forest management. Urban Forest Strategy Priority Issue 1 - Expand, Preserve and Improve the Urban Forest Long
		Term Strategies Sub-issue
		1: Increase Urban Tree Canopy Across All Ownerships 1.  Actions: a.  Work
		with NGO’s and DOEE to increase tree planting on private property b.  Work with DCPS, DCPL, DCHA, DGS, and DPR to
		encourage targeted tree planting and maintenance on District properties and creation
		of outdoor classrooms c.   Pursue
		greater coordination with Federal agencies for tree planting and maintenance d.  Increase
		coordination with District agencies to review and advise on Capital Improvement Projects e.  Plant in
		street tree boxes until fully stocked f.    Increase tree species diversity when planting
		on District property g.  Complete land cover
		assessments at 5-year increments h.  Increase
		access to trees for all landowners i.    Improve tree preservation during
		new or significant construction and infrastructure improvement Sub-issue
		2: Protect and Improve Environmental Health 1.  Actions: a.  Increase
		tree planting across MS4 areas b.  Remove
		impervious surfaces across all property ownerships as practicable c.   Support deployment of green infrastructure d.  Continue tree planting in the public Right of Way e.  Diversify
		the urban forest to create greater ecological benefit f.    Use reused urban wood material to support water
		quality improvements and streambank stabilization and restoration projects g.  Encourage the US Forest Service to continue to
		support research on managing pests and disease outbreaks in the urban forest Sub-issue
		3: Expand Resiliency Across the District Using Urban Forestry 1.  Actions: a.  Continue
		the urban wood material reuse program to extend the “useful life” of DC’s trees
		and prolong trees’ carbon sequestration b.  Use green
		infrastructure techniques to assist with stormwater management c.   Increase tree planting across MS4 areas d.  Continue
		to prioritize tree preservation as a stormwater runoff mitigation strategy e.  Support
		stream restoration programs f.    Expand tree canopy in District neighborhoods
		where climate impacts such as urban warming and flooding are most severe, and populations
		are highly vulnerable. g.  Expand
		tree canopy in areas of the city with greatest capacity for new tree planting. h.  Continue
		to work with District partners including: DOEE, DPR, DCPS, DGS, HSEMA, OSSE, DOH,
		DPW, DC Water, local utilities, such as Pepco, and nonprofit partners, such as
		Casey Trees i.    Expand partnerships to include District agencies
		such as DHCD j.    Remove impervious surfaces between tree boxes
		whenever possible k.   Enhance
		urban and ultra-urban soils to support tree growth and increase water percolation Sub-issue
		4: Management for a More Resilient Forest 1.  Actions a.  Diversify the urban forest by
		expanding the age classes across the District and choosing
		climate-ready trees b.  Manage the urban forest for pests and pathogens
		and work proactively to prevent infestation c.   Support and expand forest health expertise in the
		District d.  Develop a response plan to emerging situations
		that threaten forest health e.  Match tree and site characteristics
		when planting to optimize gray infrastructure sustainability f.    Support rapid response actions g.  Manage and inventory resources
		to track and prevent potential need for reactive management, such as continuously
		inspect trees for health and safety h.  Pursue innovative mature tree management
		and preservation across all property ownerships i.    Ensure
		adequate soil volumes for trees on public spaces Priority Issue 2: Cultivate an Urban Forest that is Equitable, Inclusive and Accessible Long Term Strategies Sub-issue
		1: Build UCF Program Capacity 1. Actions a. Build and expand on relationships with other District
		and federal agencies (such as DCHA and the Office of Aging) and nonprofit organizations b. Proactively engaging communities with varying outreach
		methods c. Support the Urban Forest Advisory Council when
		engaging and expanding partnerships and coordinating with District agencies on activities d. Continue open source sharing
		of information through the urban forestry online presence e. Use transparency to build trust
		and confidence within the community f. Build and expand awareness of urban forestry resources g. Strengthen engagement with individual residents
		and local and regional organizations to help them participate in and advocate
		for urban forestry h. Provide
		financial assistance to local and regional NGO’s who are working with target populations Sub-issue 2: Make Urban Forestry Benefits Accessible 1. Actions a. Expand urban forest resources in communities where there is need b. Increase outreach and dialogue with non-English speaking audiences c. Create and enhance outdoor classrooms on park, at recreation centers or on school properties d. Activate open spaces as components of the urban forest available for public use e. Increase exposure of urban forestry as a potential career f. Support community stewardship to promote long term social and environmental benefits at a neighborhood level Priority Issue 3:
		Multi-Jurisdictional Priority Areas Long
		Term Strategies Sub-issue
		1: Mid-Atlantic Shared Stewardship 1. Actions a. Use of
		the urban forest to support the Chesapeake Bay - Shared Stewardship Agreement- Chesapeake Forest Restoration Strategy b. Continue
		to participate in the Chesapeake Tree Canopy Network. c. Continue
		collaboration and coordination with regional agencies d. Continue
		collaborative efforts for issues such as integrated water quality, stream restoration,
		and riparian stabilization efforts e. Ongoing involvement in Mid-Atlantic Cooperative Forest Health Protection Federal-State Cooperators f. Continue participation in MAC-ISA Sub-issue
		2: Interjurisdictional Coordination in Urban Forestry 1. Actions a. Continue
		to work with District partners including: DOEE, DPR, DCPS, DGS, HSEMA, OSSE, DOH,
		DPW, DC Water, local utilities, such as Pepco, to implement comprehensive and integrated
		best forest management practices b. Continue
		participation in COG c. Continue to participate in the NCPC planning, development,
		and guidance processes d. Continue
		membership and leadership within NMSFA and NASF e. Continue collaboration and coordination with NPS,
		GSA, AOC, USDA, and other federal entities National Priority Accomplishments: Years 2010 through 2020 1. Conserve and Manage Working Forest Landscapes for Multiple Values and Uses FAP Priority Issue 1: Increase Urban Tree Canopy across all Ownerships Strategy 1: Protect and enhance urban tree canopyStrategy 2: Manage and protect urban forests in urban growth and development areas 2. Protect Forests from Threats Priority Issue 1: Increase Urban Tree Canopy across all Ownerships Strategy 3: Identify and manage threats to the DC urban forest - exotic invasive pest speciesStrategy 4: Detect, monitor and evaluate forest pests and forest health conditions 3. Enhance Public Benefits from Trees and Forests Priority Issue 2: Protect and improve air and water quality Priority Issue 3: Build UCF Program Capacity in Washington, DC Strategy 7: Protect and enhance impaired watersheds in Washington, DCStrategy 10: Encourage the use of LID and other green techniques to mitigate water quality issues Strategy 12: Educate citizens on the importance of urban forestry and its multiple benefitsStrategy 13: Support and enhance green jobs See Accomplishments Full Documents and Resource Plans Related Plans and Policies Get Involved Keep me Updated Sign up for a community account and "Follow Project" for timely information, event notices, and to be a part of this amazing process of conserving, protect, and managing our urban forests! Additional Contact Information For more information, please email ufaddot@dc.gov

title: Social Characteristics of DC Census Tracts
description: Household type, Education, Disability, Language, Computer/Internet Use, and more.  This service is updated annually with American Community Survey (ACS) 5-year data.  Contact:  District of Columbia, Office of Planning.  Email:  planning@dc.govGeography:  Census TractsCurrent Vintage: 2016-2020ACS Table(s): DP02Data downloaded from: Census Bureau's API for American Community Survey Date of API call: March 18, 2022National Figures: data.census.gov The United States Census Bureau's American Community Survey (ACS):About the SurveyGeography & ACSTechnical DocumentationNews & UpdatesThis ready-to-use layer can be used within ArcGIS Pro, ArcGIS Online, its configurable apps, dashboards, Story Maps, custom apps, and mobile apps. Data can also be exported for offline workflows. Please cite the Census and ACS when using this data. Data Note from the Census:Data are based on a sample and are subject to sampling variability. The degree of uncertainty for an estimate arising from sampling variability is represented through the use of a margin of error. The value shown here is the 90 percent margin of error. The margin of error can be interpreted as providing a 90 percent probability that the interval defined by the estimate minus the margin of error and the estimate plus the margin of error (the lower and upper confidence bounds) contains the true value. In addition to sampling variability, the ACS estimates are subject to nonsampling error (for a discussion of nonsampling variability, see Accuracy of the Data).  The effect of nonsampling error is not represented in these tables. Data Processing Notes:This layer is updated automatically when the most current vintage of ACS data is released each year, usually in December. The layer always contains the latest available ACS 5-year estimates. It is updated annually within days of the Census Bureau's release schedule. Click here to learn more about ACS data releases.Boundaries come from the US Census TIGER geodatabases. Boundaries are updated at the same time as the data updates (annually), and the boundary vintage appropriately matches the data vintage as specified by the Census. These are Census boundaries with water and/or coastlines clipped for cartographic purposes. For census tracts, the water cutouts are derived from a subset of the 2010 AWATER (Area Water) boundaries offered by TIGER. For state and county boundaries, the water and coastlines are derived from the coastlines of the 500k TIGER Cartographic Boundary Shapefiles. The original AWATER and ALAND fields are still available as attributes within the data table (units are square meters). Field alias names were created based on the Table Shells file available from the American Community Survey Summary File Documentation page.Data processed using R statistical package and ArcGIS Desktop.Margin of Error was not included in this layer but is available from the Census Bureau.  Contact the Office of Planning for more information about obtaining Margin of Error values.

title: Master Address Repository Viewer
description: The Master Address Repository (MAR) Viewer is part of the District's location services documented in Addressing in DC. It makes locating addresses or place name as easy as possible by employing spell check and lists of street names or property aliases. Find the Ward a property falls in, or its police district, and more details. The MAR Viewer is currently in Beta mode with planned functionality improvements coming soon. The current DC Location Search continues to be available.

In addition to sampling variability, the ACS estimates are subject to nonsampling error (for a discussion of nonsampling variability, see Accuracy of the Data).  The effect of nonsampling error is not represented in these tables. Data Processing Notes:This layer is updated automatically when the most current vintage of ACS data is released each year, usually in September. The layer always contains the latest available ACS 5-year estimates. It is updated annually within days of the Census Bureau's release schedule. Click here to learn more about ACS data releases.Boundaries come from the US Census TIGER geodatabases. Boundaries are updated at the same time as the data updates (annually), and the boundary vintage appropriately matches the data vintage as specified by the Census. These are Census boundaries with water and/or coastlines clipped for cartographic purposes. For census tracts, the water cutouts are derived from a subset of the 2010 AWATER (Area Water) boundaries offered by TIGER. For state and county boundaries, the water and coastlines are derived from the coastlines of the 500k TIGER Cartographic Boundary Shapefiles. The original AWATER and ALAND fields are still available as attributes within the data table (units are square meters). Field alias names were created based on the Table Shells file available from the American Community Survey Summary File Documentation page.Data processed using R statistical package and ArcGIS Desktop.Margin of Error was not included in this layer but is available from the Census Bureau.  Contact the Office of Planning for more information about obtaining Margin of Error values.

title: Business Characteristics of DC (District-wide)
description: This layer contains data on the number of employees and number of establishments for selected 2-digit North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes.  This is shown by District boundaries. The full CBP data set (available at census.gov) is updated annually to contain the most currently released CBP data.  Current Vintage: 2020CBP Table: CB2000CBPData downloaded from: Census Bureau's API for County Business Patterns Date of API call: January 11, 2023 The United States Census Bureau's County Business Patterns Program (CBP):About this ProgramDataTechnical DocumentationNews & UpdatesThis ready-to-use layer can be used within ArcGIS Pro, ArcGIS Online, its configurable apps, dashboards, Story Maps, custom apps, and mobile apps. For census tracts, the water cutouts are derived from a subset of the 2010 AWATER (Area Water) boundaries offered by TIGER. For state and county boundaries, the water and coastlines are derived from the coastlines of the 500k TIGER Cartographic Boundary Shapefiles. The original AWATER and ALAND fields are still available as attributes within the data table (units are square meters). Blank values represent industries where there either were no businesses in that industry and that geography OR industries where the data had to be withheld to avoid disclosing data for individual companies.  Users should visit data.census.gov or Census Business Builder for more details on these withheld records.Data processed by the Office of Planning on R statistical software and ESRI ArcGIS Desktop.

title: Zoning to Property Lot Query Layer
description: The DC Office of Zoning uses this query layer, which is a spatial join between the ZR16 zoning polygons and the Common Ownership Lots, to show zoning information at the lot level. This layer aids the online zoning map to show zoning information by address. The PREMISEADD field is the address that is identified as the lot’s primary address for tax purposes. Note that this field also contains the city/state/zip code; and the addresses in the query layer will not make up a comprehensive list because of the many-to-one relationship. There can be multiple addresses on single lot.

title: Dockless Bike and Scooter Corral on National Mall
description: Geofencing of parking areas for dockless vehicles (bikes and scooters) around the National Mall.

title: Recycling in DC: Pathway to Zero Waste
description: This StoryMap features interactive maps and visuals, educational videos and raw data. Scroll down and make sure to stop along the way, as this StoryMap demonstrates how;

title: Moving Violations Issued in June 2021
description: Moving citation locations in the District of Columbia. The Vision Zero data contained in this layer pertain to moving violations issued by the District of Columbia's Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and partner agencies with the authority. For example, DC's enforcement camera program cites speeders, blocking the box, and other moving offenses.. Moving violation locations are summarized ticket counts based on time of day, week of year, year, and category of violation.Data was originally downloaded from the District Department of Motor Vehicle's eTIMS meter work order management system. Data was exported into DDOT’s SQL server, where the Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) geocoded citation data to the street segment level. Data was then visualized using the street segment centroid coordinates.

title: Parking Violations Issued in June 2021
description: Parking citation locations in the District of Columbia. The Vision Zero data contained in this layer pertain to parking violations issued by the District of Columbia's Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and partner agencies with the authority. For example, the District Department of Transportation's (DDOT) traffic control officers write parking violations to prevent congestion through enforcement and control at intersections.Parking violation locations are summarized ticket counts based on time of day, week of year, year, and category of violation.Data was originally downloaded from the District Department of Motor Vehicle's eTIMS meter work order management system.
